text:
Good recipe, though I replaced the oil with butter and used less flour.

Another reviewer asked why the baking soda bath is necessary: Old world Germans used to dip their brezels (pretzels) in a solution of sodium hydroxide (lye) and water before baking. Lye is a very strong and caustic alkaline. Because most people aren't comfortable mixing lye and water to make pretzels, baking soda - a much weaker alkaline - is now used in most pretzel recipes.

Once the pretzels begin baking, a 'Maillard reaction' occurs. This is a chemical reaction sortof like carmelization, which allows the exterior crust to become a deep rich brown color. The reaction accelerates in an alkaline environment, which - you guessed it - has been provided by the baking soda bath. The baking soda, and resulting reaction, is also responsible for the unique taste of a pretzel.

Without the baking soda bath the pretzel exterior ends up pale/white, and taste more like bread. This baking soda / lye bath step is paramount in making a pretzel a pretzel.

text:
I have gotten into baking breads, etc. since my wife bought a baking stone. This recipe is very good. The pretzels didn't last long. 

Here's what I will do next time I make a batch:
After dividing the dough into 12 pcs., roll the dough out into a rope at least 20-24" long. The dough will expand. 

Spray "I Can't Believe Its Butter" after I place the pretzels on the sheet and sprinkled coarse salt. I tried this on 3 pretzels from my first batch and they were better tasting. 

Use a rack that's up higher in the oven to prevent burning of the pretzels bottoms. 

Make sure my wife stands over me to supervise.

text:
WOW!! These pretzels are absolutely amazing.  They were soft and chewy on the inside, awesome flavor, with that great authentic thin "pretzel" crust on the outside.  I spooned the melted butter over them after baking which soaked in and was just perfect.  My husband described them as "heavenly", haha, never heard him use that one before!  Next time I will bake at maybe 415 or lower to keep them from being too brown before being done in the middle.  I've been searching for a pretzel recipe and this one was much easier than most that I found.  Tip: let dough rise in your oven, no heat, just turn on the oven light.  Provides a draft free, warm place for dough to double flawlessly.  Also use a damp kitchen town instead of plastic wrap to cover bowl and you won't have a dry crust to your risen dough.  I do this with all of my bread recipes!

text:
These are better than Auntie Anne's or Pretzel Time!! My kids ate all 12 within 10 minutes - I couldn't believe how good these were !! I wish I had made a triple recipe.  They all said they tasted BETTER than the ones at the mall - I agree ! And a lot cheaper making them yourself ! I was puzzled why the recipe called for them to be dunked in a baking soda and water mixture - if anyone knows why, please explain? I did it anyways. The changes I made = I used 4 cups of flour instead of 5.  I used organic pure cane sugar  and All Natural sea salt and instead of vegetable oil (I used super healthy 'Organic Virgin Coconut Oil by Tropical Traditions') and also used that to grease the bowl the dough was to rise in. After putting the pretzels in the soda/water mixture, I put them on parchment paper which I sprayed with Olive Oil spray (instead of greasing) and then I sprinkled Kosher salt on the tops of them (on a few others I did cinnamon w/Raw sugar).  The oven temp. seemed way to high even at 415, so on the second batch I decreased it to 400 degrees for 8 minutes - they got browned very quickly on top.  After removing them from the oven I brushed melted UNsalted butter over the tops and bottoms of them - saturating them with butter (I did not put any more salt on after the butter).  
Loved the recipe -- the rolling took a while,didn't have a lot of patience - I didn't roll them on the table, I just rolled them between my hands vertically until the 'snake' became long and thin.

Update to my review from over a year ago... I'm still making these pretzels and love them because they are soooo easy.  I've found the sea salt is the absolute best thing to top them with (but be sure to use kosher salt in the dough),


Excellent recipe!  I've found it is best to add 3.5 cups of flour and slowly mix in the final half cup as I'm kneading the dough.  I've made these at least 4 times in the past 2 weeks.  They freeze up great!  Just thaw and pop in the oven for a couple minutes for an awesome snack!!

text:
I couldn't understanding why other reviewers had such a hard time with the dough....then it dawned on me, I did not follow the instructions.  I looked at the water, yeast, salt sugar content, mixed all those together and THEN added as much flour as it could hold.  That is what I do for all breads, because the amount of flour can vary according to type, weather etc.  I found it very easy to knead and roll out.  I faced the problem of them sticking to the pan (I don't have a non stick pan).  I oiled the pan well, but the water from the soda mixture caused them to stick somewhat.  I was suprised I did not read another reviewer having the same problem.  We brush with butter when they come out of the oven and drizzle with honey.  Thanks for the great recipe.

text:
As I was reading the reviews, I was pretty unsure about how it was going to turn out. I halved the recipe, because it is just my boyfriend and I, and this was my only mistake! I made them as the recipe stated, using the dough hook on my mixer. I added flour until the dough was no longer sticky, so I do not know exactly how much I ended up using. When rolling out the dough I came up with a trick. You need to make them much thinner than you think, so i rolled small pieces into thin (like about the thickness of a finger) sticks, then joined two together to get them as long as I needed them to twist. I made the dough quite thin, but they puff up a lot, do not worry! I also dipped my pretzels in the baking soda mix, which I think really makes the whole pretzel. When they cook they get this browned yumminess on the bottom, that tastes JUST like the ones at the mall. I just drizzled them with butter and a little kosher salt when they came out warm... they were gone right after that. Will make again and soon!

text:
Excellent! I used to work in one of the pretzel places in the mall- and this recipe is on point! A couple of tips though: yes, you will need to add a bit more water, but also about a teaspoon more oil as well- this will help smooth out the dough. The soda bath is necessary for browning- and if you expect the salt to stick this is the best way to do it (add salt after wetting the pretzels). If you have trouble dipping the pretzels, wet a paper towel with the soda mixture and blot them instead. Also- it's best not to flour your surface when rolling pretzels. If you add a bit more oil as I said before, then the dough will be smooth and not stick. When you divide, cutting the dough ball as if it were pizza slices will help with the rolling as well. Start at the middle of the piece and work your way out to the ends. The cut dough will dry quickly and become awkward to work with- to avoid this keep plastic wrap on what you are not working with at the moment. When they come out of the oven use a paper towel to blot butter on them- it will help to keep them soft- if you are opposed to butter then cooking sprays are just as well.

text:
I've been using this recipe for a few years, and have found it to be my most popular bread. My friends STRONGLY encourage me to bring pretzels to most events.
A few recommendations- use higher gluten flour to get a little more chewiness. I always need at least 1 1/2 cups of water, sometimes more. The softer the dough, the easier shaping the pretzels is. I bring the soda solution almost to a simmer and soak the pretzels for about 10 seconds each. I also only use 2 or 3 tsp of yeast.

text:
Really good! I did knead this more with my mixer for another 3-4 min. It needed to rise for almost 2 hrs. before it looked ready. When I dumped it out of the bowl the dough was perefect. Soft, pliable like it's suppose to be. After dipping in the soda water I allowed the pretzels to sit for another 15 min. for a 2nd small rising. I used an egg wash before baking. THEN I applied the butter after they came out of the oven. This is a must.!!  It's what keeps the pretzels from becoming hard like a dough does after baking. I did have to use MORE flour as I kneaded the dough..not less. I recommend this recipe for intermediate and advanced bakers, tho.

text:
Good recipe!  I used to work at Pretzel Time as a kid, and this recipe is very close to how they make it.  It's just a little heavy on the sugar and flour.  Next time I make I'll probably cut back the flour by 1/2-1 cup and the sugar by just a couple tablespoons or so.  For the baking soda bath cool or lukewarm water works better for the dough, and there's way too much baking soda in that bath.  Maybe half is needed otherwise you can really taste the baking soda.  Also no need to flour the surface if done right; the dough will slide on the surface instead of rolling properly.  Rolling tips: after you let the dough rise, punch it down, roll it into a ball, throw it in an air tight plastic baggy, and throw it in the fridge for an hour or so (just like in the mall.  Letting the dough cool makes it more elastic.  Next take your cool dough ball out of the fridge and it's baggy.  Again do not flour the surface.  Cut a 4 oz strip of dough off.  Now before rolling dip your finger tips in the baking soda bath and rub what you get on your fingers all over your hands.  Start in the middle with both hands and roll using medium pressure.  As you roll work your hands out to the ends.  You're done when the dough is about the thickness of a finger.  Grab each end and slap on your surface like a jump rope about two or three times.  Be careful here not to use too much force or the dough will tear.  Next form your pretzel either mid air (advanced) or on your rolling surface.

text:
This is an awesome recipe! I'm looking for items to make for a bake sale. So glad I found this recipe! Even tried another recipe from another site to compare and those came out tasting more like bread sticks than pretzels! The baking soda water bath is key. Also I had such a hard time using flour to roll the pretzels and found a how-to video from Auntie Anne's pretzel company online and it suggested not using flour while rolling the pretzels and it worked! I took the advice of other reviewers and only used 4 cups of flour. And use a clean towel or a few sheets of papertowel for blotting excess water after dipping pretzels--also on the how-to video. And so I made these soooo many different ways, too! Salt, Cinnamon and sugar, cinnamon raisin, apple cinnamon (just dice two small apples in small pieces add it and 1 tblspoon of apple pie spice to ingredients while mixing dough. It makes the dough a little stickier when rolling out, but well worth it in the end!), pumpkin spice (used all 5 cups of flour and just a little more and add 1 cup of pumpkin puree, and 1 tblspoon pumpkin pie spice to dough while mixing).This recipe is awesome, do yourself a favor and try it!

text:
These are very yummy and I have others ask for the recipe. The first time I made these, I made 1/2 butter/kosher salt and 1/2 cinnamon sugar/honey butter. The cinnamon ones were the favorite!  They would be excellent for bread sticks as well I'm sure! 
Here's what I do: I cut the flour down to 4 cups not 5- definately do this! Also- 4 tsp. of yeast equals 2 packets. I let the dough rise 1 1/2 hours on the counter and then in the fridge overnight, I spread the dough out on the counter and use a pizza cutter to divide it into 16 pieces (not 12). That way there are more servings and they are still definately big enough. Don't skip the baking soda step. If I want to make salted pretzels I sprinkle the kosher salt (sparingly) on before baking (for cinnamon sugar of course I don't add this step). Bake on a high rack in the oven at 415 degrees- not 450. When they come out I brush on melted butter. For cinnamon sugar pretzels (our favorite!) I brush on butter mixed with 2 T. honey and sprinkle with a mix of 1/2 cup sugar and 1 tsp. cinnamon. They are very tasty like this! I think next time I will try twisted breadsticks with a garlic/butter mix for the brushing.

text:
This recipe is excellent, easy to follow and never fails to impress! I've made these pretzels with different spices as well as different cheeses - cheddar is always a big hit.   But. there are three very important things to note in order to get the best results possible:  1) Make sure to add the flour gradually. This will help make sure the dough doesn't become too dry. 2) Dampen your hands periodically with a little bit of water when rolling out the dough. It will help give you greater grip and control without over-drying the dough from too much flour. 3) Dipping the pretzel dough in the baking soda water is necessary to get the crispy outside and soft inside, but can be brutal for your baking sheet. Make sure to use non-stick spray or oil to prevent burning and sticking.

text:
These were excellent.  One huge regret, I didn't double the recipe!  I will from now on.  The baking soda bath added a nice flavor and color.  I think next time I make this I'll play around with letting the shaped pretzels proof for a bit and boiling for about a min in the baking soda bath.  Possibly an egg wash before baking too.  I want to see if I can get the outside a touch chewier but these were far better than the mall pretzels in my opinion.  My 9 year old daughter figured out a way to shape them quickly.  She formed the dough into a small thick stick and then picked it up by both ends and swung it around like a jump rope until it was long and thin.  Worked great and really fast.  450 was too hot for our oven so we lowered it to 400 and they turned out great, perfectly browned and cooked inside after 8 minutes. We only needed to use about 4 cups of flour.  Thanks for a great recipe!  We will definitely be making these again!!  What a fun activity for kids too.

Display Name:
Risa

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is a good recipe. Tastes just like the pretzels from the stores. I didn't change anything. I added 1 tbsp water as suggested in the recipe because the dough was a bit dry. My dough at first was a little mushy after the 1 tbsp but after kneading it a bit, the water was absorbed leaving a drier, workable dough ( dough will be still a bit sticky but this is normal). Rolling the dough was  A LOT of fun, at least for me it was. Give yourself plenty of counter space and start rolling inward than outward, slowly stretching the dough (don't be afraid to really pull the dough). The pretzels brown nicer if your pretzels are thin. I would advise baking no more than 4 pretzels per cookie sheet so you won't crowd them together and mess up the shape. I did not flour my surface because I saw a video where an aunt anne cook did not use any and surprisingly the dough didn't stick. Another tip is, after you dip the pretzels in the baking soda mixture, rest the bottom of the pretzel on a clean, dry dishcloth a few seconds so you won't have too much water accumulating underneath the pretzel on the cookie sheet. This can cause  your pretzel to brown too much underneath. To make cinnamon sugar topping, dip hot pretzel in 1/2 cup butter and then in a mixture of 1/4 cup sugar and 1/2 tsp cinnamon (or more if you'd like). You should also rotate the sheet 180 degrees after 5 mins to evenly brown the pretzels.

12/12/2010 - I made these this morning, and they are already almost gone.  Pretty sad that four of us have eaten 10 pretzels already, but they are so good.  These are buttery, sweet, and so soft.  My husband has already requested another batch of these.  Your house will smell like you are in a mall walking past one of those pretzel shops.  Definitely a must try recipe!
I am rating this because of the low rating before this.  It is NOT too much baking soda.  Boiling the pretzels in the water with baking soda gives it the crust that it needs.  I have done this many times with pretzels, bagels, and pretzel bread.  Try the recipe (or at least read it all the way) before giving a negative rating.  So sad!

text:
Very easy and good. I used to be a manager at a pretzel shop years ago and this is how we made them. A few tips... After dipping pretzel in the baking soda/water mixture, place on a dish towel or layer of paper towels to dry the bottom off, this will help prevent the bottoms burning. Also, use parchment paper. Oven should be at 400-415 (parchment paper cannot be used above 420). Turn baking sheet halfway through for even browning. I used tongs to dip the face of the pretzel in a pie plate of melted butter as soon as they came out of the oven. Next time I will try adding raisins to the dough for a breakfast pretzel.

Display Name:
Patty M.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
As always, i read the most helpful reviews before making these. i made the following modifications based on the reviews and the results were spot on.    i followed other suggestions and used 4 cups of flour. The only other modifications I made were adding vanilla brown sugar in the dough.  I proofed the yeast by dissolving it into 1/4 cup warm water and one teaspoon of sugar and let it sit until bubbly, around 10 minutes.   I put all the ingredients into my bread machine and let it do all the work.  I made a few in the traditional pretzel shape, but most i rolled into ropes about the size of a finger and made pretzel sticks. I dipped the pretzels into the water/baking soda solution and let it sit for a few minutes. if you are making traditional style pretzels, they may become untwisted in the water, just reshape them on the baking sheet.   The key is using parchment paper to bake these or they will stick, because the water solution makes the dough very sticky.    I also followed the advice of others and reduced the oven temp to 400 degrees, and baked for 8 minutes. I did not sprinkle with salt before baking.    Immediately after taking the pretzels out of the oven, I brushed them liberally with melted butter. I sprinkled some with a sugar/cinnamon mix and topped the others with just a little kosher salt.   My son inhaled them, and hubby moaned with delight while devouring them.  They both said they were as good as the Mall pretzels. All 12 were gone in 10 minutes.

city:

country:
None
text:
These turned out delicious! And even better the next day!! I made them with bread flour instead of all purpose and they came out wonderfully soft and slightly chewy. Otherwise, I stuck to the recipe, as is. We have made a lot of pretzels and find the shaping annoying, so we made bites instead. Also, for those having trouble with rising issues, etc., this recipe calls for active dry yeast, you should check to make sure you aren't using bread machine yeast, which is instant and needs no preparation in sugar water. When using instant (bread machine) yeast, just mix it in with the dry ingredients, then add the warm water as usual. I hope this is helpful. It's also important to keep in mind that flour packs down, so if you aren't shaking it up a bit before measuring, then you are probably actually getting more than the required amount. Loosen your flour before measuring it out and you may find that you don't need less after all.

text:
One Word - AWESOME!!!  To make a bit more healthy I substituted 2 of the 3 cups of white flour for whole wheat flour.  I used my kitchen aid to do all the kneading.  To let the dough rise, I heated my oven to 200 degrees and then turned it off for about 15 or 20 minutes and placed the kneaded dough in the oven.  It doubled in about an hour and 20 minutes.  Instead of greasing a pan, I used parchmant paper.  Once in the over, they only took about 6 minutes to bake up golden brown.  As soon as I got them out of the oven, I sprayed some low calorie fat free spray butter on them and brushed the butter into them with a pastry brush.  The result is simply outstanding!!!  I've tried numerous other pretzel recipes and this one is by far the best and actually the easiest too. Thanks for the great recipe!!!!

text:
These came out awesome!  I used all 5 cups of flour and ended up adding about 5-6 tbsp of water, and wetting my hands a little while kneading the dough.  When I divided the dough, I initially only made 6 sections because it didn't look like enough to make a big pretzel, and the three pretzels that I rolled were 3/4"-1" thick, so my first three pretzels came out HUGE!  For the second batch, I divided the remaining three dough balls in half (six pieces) and made to sure to roll them until they were about 1/2" thick and came out about 24" long, and the pretzels still came out pretty big.  I periodically put the pretzels I finished shaping onto the pan after the baking soda bath, and they rose a lot more since the pan was still warm from the first batch.  I baked them in 400 degrees for about 10 minutes, and they came out perfect!  The first batch (the big ones) may have been in there for a minute longer as I realized I had to go fetch potholders, but the first batch came out the best!  As soon as they come out of the oven, I soaked them in butter, but did not add any more salt.  Slightly (barely) crusty on the outside, nice and chewy on the inside.  These pretzels are slightly sweet, just the right amount of salty, and definitely taste best warm.  I personally like these pretzels better than the ones at the mall.

text:
My kids simply love these soft pretzels - theyre almost like Aunt Anne's pretzels!! Followed tips from past reviews and reduced flour amt to 4 cups. I only used 3 1/2 tsp instant yeast as i didnt want the yeasty taste tht some reviewers complained abt. Also halved the amt of baking soda cos didnt want strong metallic taste. I sprinkled some parmesan cheese on some pretzels just b4 baking n baked at 400F for 8 mins on a lined baking sheet. After removing them from the oven, i immediately brushed melted butter on every pretzel. I sprinkled the ones without cheese with cinnamon sugar. So everyone in the family was happy - the kids with the savoury cheesy ones n me - the sweet cinnamon ones! :)

text:
This recipe is circulating thru my family like wildfire right now and we are all having fun comparing notes:  First of all it IS a bit of a pain pulling the knots out of the water solution,  all you have to do is roll them out to hamburger bun size discs, rest, dip and bake (awesome sliced and Muenster or smoked swiss added like a sandwhich).  If yours don't taste like mall pretzels, you probably didnt dip them long enuff, I use the microwave and dip them while it's running (on High-20 seconds)  they should puff up a bit like a dumpling. Lastly, your flour must be fresh,  those of you who thought they were "bland"  were probably using "tired"  or stale flour.  Love this recipe!!!

text:
My husband insisted, with his mouth full of pretzel, that I write a review for these!  They are yummy!  Do note that you will need 1/4 to 1/2 cup of melted butter to brush on the pretzels once they're cooked.  The butter is mentioned in the description of the recipe but isn't on the ingredient list.  Also, to get pretzels that look more like the ones you buy and less like fat little knots: 1. Roll the dough ropes as long as possible.  2. Let them rest a few minutes and then roll them even longer.  3.  Work as quickly as possible while shaping the pretzels and dipping them into the soda water.  They seem to retain their size once they're sitting on the baking sheet.

text:
**Use Bread Flour!!!**I made these the first time with regular all-purpose flour and they were pretty good, but kinda fell apart when I dipped them, and were difficult to reshape.  My husband wanted me to make them again, but we didn't have enough flour on hand so he went up to the store and made the best mistake ever!  He came home with bread flour.  I used that instead, not knowing what to expect, and the pretzels went from being pretty good to absolutely amazing!!!  They held together great, and they looked and tasted better than the real thing!  I will only use bread flour from now on.  It makes the perfect pretzel!!

text:
Excellent recipe!  If you have a bread machine.... use it!  I cut the recipe in half to fit my bread machine.  I placed all liquid ingredients first, then all dry ingredients.  Put the machine on the dough cycle and let it do all the work.  No need to proof the yeast.  Very simple.  Then I followed the rest of the directions on the recipe for forming the pretzels.  Next time, I would just dip the tops of the pretzels in the baking soda mixture... I think that the bottoms got a little too brown because I dunked the whole pretzel.

text:
WOW!  I was skeptical as I was rolling these out bc I didnt feel like the dough was as shape-able as I would have liked and I am not an experienced bread maker, but they turned out SO good!

I made the dough in my bread machine on the dough setting. I did decreased the flour to 4 C as other reviewers suggested and I did lower the baking temp to 400 - 8 mins was perfect.  Also let eacg pretzel soak in the b. soda/water soln for 10 seconds each.

YUM!!!

text:
After reading 6 pages of reviews, I went with 4 cups of flour, 2 white, 2 whole wheat. I reduced the sugar to 1/4 cup,(  used brown sugar).I reduced salt to 3/4 teaspoon, and baking soda to 1/4 cup, water to 2 cups. Instead of making traditional pretzels, I shaped them into hamburger buns. I made the buns 3 1/2" in diameter, and 1/2" thick. To use them, slice bun in 1/2 and you have a fantastic hamburger, or sloppy joe bun! Next time I will try Hot dog buns! Wow! Excellent! Thank you!

None
text:
My family and I love this recipe. I did read the other reviews and used only 4 cups of flour. When I first tried it, I made it four times in one week! Unfortunately, I ran out of all-purpose flour and ended up using 1/2 cup of whole wheat and 3 1/2 cups of all-purpose. The pretzels came out even better! I think they were easier to roll out. For best results, follow the editors advice and roll out all 12 pieces and then start at the first piece and roll them out again. Also 400 degrees, on a top rack in the oven and parchment paper is a must :-)

As other reviewers stated there is too much flour for the abount of liquid. I suggest incorperating your flour slowly until the dough has "taken" all it can, I found that to be about 3 1/2 cups. country:
None
text:
Followed the recipe on the my first attempt.  Pretzels seemed to stick to the pan, and the pretzels seemed smaller than what I expected.  The second time around, I used whole wheat white flour, and sprayed my pan with a non-stick spray.  Also, after dipping in the warm water/baking soda bath, I left on a cooling rack to let some of the moisture to drip off.  I managed to get a total of 16 pretzels, and received raves for the finished product.  My son, who loves Auntie Anne's pretzels, absolutely loved these.  I will save this recipe and use again for sure.

text:
I made this recipe twice and it came out great both times. The first time I used way too much flour and boiled the pretzels (instead of just using warm water) and they still came out great! The second time, I rolled the dough into ropes, then cut them into 1-inch pieces to make pretzel bites. I cut the cooking time to 5 minutes, dipped them in butter, and sprinkled them with cinnamon sugar or salt and froze some of them to heat back up later. My only issue was a slight baking soda flavor with the bites, but that might be because I didn't pat them dry before I baked them. Great recipe!

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2007-11-05T13:45:12.423
helpfulCount:
5
userID:
874388
Display Name:
Cyndi Ivy Fontes
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
90
favoritesCount:
311
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2766513.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very good recipe.  The taste is fabulous.  I baked these twice yesterday.  The first batch I baked at 450 and the bottoms were burnt even at 7 minutes.  I baked the second batch at 415.  They browned nicely on the bottom, however were not very brown on top.  I did use the 5 cups of flour as written.  However, I added around 1/4 cup more water.  The dough needs to be a little tacky.  It shouldn't be dry.  The second time I used 1/4 c sugar.  There was no hint of sweetness at all.  My husband preferred the version with less sugar.  My kids and I preferred the ones with the 1/2 c sugar.  Slightly less than 1/2 c may be the happy medium.  Next time I will try making garlic bread sticks with this recipe.  (Will only use 1/4 c sugar for that.)  I did not brush with butter.  Don't skip the baking soda process or the pretzels will not brown at all.  I used my stand mixer to knead the dough.
***UPDATE:  I've made these several times now.  1 3/4 c of water seems to work well.  I put 1 tsp of molasses in with the baking soda bath.  This gives them a browner color.

text:
After reading the other reviews, I started out with only 4 cups of flour and then slowly added the other cup while I was kneading it.  I divided the dough into 12 pieces and then halved each piece after rolling them out.  I dipped them in the soda bath and then placed them the pan that I liberally sprayed with cooking spray.  I spread butter on each other the little pretzels and just sprinkled regular table salt.  When they came out I put more butter and ate about 7 right there at the counter!  The table salt added just enough saltiness and the bread was so soft and good.  The next day they were still good, but more the consistency of a bagel.  I'd say to eat them right away and they'd be great as dinner rolls with garlic butter.

text:
Go for it! You will love them! I saw a reviewer saying this recipe would be for intermediate or advance bakers... NOT true. Let me tell you, I am the worst baker in the history of fire! I can't even bake pre-made cookie dough without burning or undercooking; but I was able to make DELICIOUS pretzels with this recipe because it definitely is fool-proof! Hubby was a little worried this would be going straight to the trash can, especially after I asked him "what does 'knead' mean?" haha, but he really liked them. I soaked the pretzels and sprinkled just a little sea salt (only kind I had). After they baked I brushed melted butter and sprinkled a bit more salt. AWESOME! I had to leave the house when the dough was resting, so I accidentally let it rise for almost 3 hours. After researching the term "knead" I know I can make even better pretzels next time, hehe, but I encourage everyone to give this a try just like I, the worst baker ever, did :)

Delicious. The only change I made was to use instant yeast (only 2 tsp instead of 4), and I only made half the baking soda mixture, and next time I'll only make a 1/4 of it...you don't need a lot. I tried NOT dipping one pretzel in the baking soda mixture, and there was a definite difference in texture and coloring...it's definitely worth it to dip it! Cinnamon sugar is our favorite coating with this one!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Excellent flavor. I did like others recommended - 4c of flour instead of 5c; 1t of kosher salt instead of 1 1/2 regular salt; baking soda bath of 2c water and 2T soda; blotted the twisted, wet pretzel dough on a dry wash cloth before transferring to parchment paper; baked at 425 degrees for 8 min. I also discovered to roll the dough 10-12 inches for every ounce of dough. A 2-ounce, 24-inch piece of dough was manageable for me; although a mall-size pretzel I guessed to be about 3 ounces of dough rolled 30-36 inches long.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Like a previous reviewer, I'd like to give this 5 stars but am only giving it 4 as I changed it a little, after reading LOTS of comments and seeing the patterns!  I used 4 cups of flour instead of 5, only 1/4 cup of sugar, and used a LOT less baking soda and water (I kept the proportions the same, but just made enough for a small bowlful - 2 tablespoons of soda with a little more than one cup of water was more than enough). The dough was just perfect - you know how you can just feel whether it's right as you start to knead...  After a few practice runs making the standard sort of pretzel with kosher salt (my husband immediately gave the result a place in his Top 5), we experimented with adding sugar and cinnamon in place of the salt - we even tried adding some raisins to the dough and rolling it up into a 'snail' or cinnamon roll - yes, I know that it's no longer a pretzel if we do that, but the result was brilliant, and with far less fat and sugar than a standard pastry of that sort.   This has become an instant favourite - both the making and the eating - and I suspect it will be made regularly! Thanks for the original recipe and for all the detailed comments which helped me adapt it for such a great result.

text:
I made these this past weekend for an Oktoberfest party and they were pretty good and not too hard to make.  They definately taste better warm out of the over (I made them the day before the party, but snitched one when they were fresh!).  Also, if you're not planning to eat them right away, wait to put the salt on.  I put it on right away and it had all absorbed into the bread by the next day.  I just put a little more butter on them and added more salt and stuck them in the over for about 4 minutes.  Turned out great!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe! My children and I made 3 batches in 3 days! They had so much fun making them that they invited friends over to make them.
We consistently made one change, per previous reviewers suggestions we adjusted the amount of flour to 4 cups. It was the perfect amount. I would adjust the sugar amount depending on what you want to do with them. If you want a sweet pretzel, keep it as is, if you want it more savory cut the amount in half. I have added cinnamon and raisins to the dough and it was delicious. I imagine the possibilities are endless.
Incidentally, don't skip the baking soda step. It is what gives the exterior a nice chewy texture.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe three times now and these pretzels are delicious.  I cut the sugar to 1/4 cup and the salt to 1 teaspoon and found that less yeast (2 1/4 tsp.) worked for me along with 1 tablespoon of gluten.  For those who are having trouble rolling out the pretzels, try dampening the surface you roll them out on with a wet paper towel.  Use the heels of your hands to roll them and move your hands outward as you roll to 22 to 24 inches.  I also let mine rise for about 30 minutes before baking them on parchment paper. They are wonderful brushed with melted butter and sprinkled with cinnamon and sugar.

text:
Great recipe, tried for the 1st time - I followed everything (after the first batch) except I thought I'd experiment a little (It's the artist in me I guess!) and, instead of dipping them into the water/baking soda mixture, I used melted butter with some garlic herb seasoning - I did this before, 1/2 through cooking and after taking them out of the oven as they were resting. Both turned out well, I always like garlic and herbs - and I think using butter enchances the flavor (plain or with garlic). When brushing them halfway through, it helps them "brown." Thanks for the recipe!!

These were super soft!!  I read TONS of reviews and was really worried about whether or not these would turn out but I was pleasantly surprised.  Only used 4 cups of flour and 3/4 tsp of salt in the dough and it was plenty.  Still had to add a tablespoon of water to it to make it workable.  Next time I'll try cinnamon and sugar on top and don't worry about the browning...it's just the baking soda/water mixture.

text:
This was a really easy recipe I found using your hands works better to mix the dough, my mother always said if you use your hands to eat it, then use your hands to make it, you dont need a fancy mixer.  Also if you melt some butter and brush it on-top it adds to the flavor of the pretzel.  Cinnamon sugar is also good on this pretzel.  Also you dont need that much Soda mixture to was way to much.  All in all it was a really great recipe, and I plan on using it all the time.  Thanks.

text:
My boyfriend LOVES pretzels. Almost every time we go to the mall, we HAVE to get a pretzel. So I decided to look up a recipe and try to make them. I looked at the reviews before hand, so I used 4 cups of flour instead of 5 and used butter instead of oil. I threw all the ingredients into my bread machine on dough cycle and VOILA! We also baked them on a little lower of a temperature, around 410°F. They were delicious and easy. Since we couldn't eat them all at once, I froze half, which were perfect when micro waved for about 30 seconds.

text:
My family loves this recipe and we make it a lot.  I start with three cups flour and then slowly add more in as needed.  I give the kids small amounts of dough to make there own pretzels.  We make all kinds of shapes and sizes.  The thinner you get your strips of dough the better.  Our favorite way to eat them is after they come out of the over we brush them all over with butter and then cover them with a cinnamon and sugar mixture.  I am not experinced with bread/yeast recipes and I have had no problems with this recipe.

text:
I followed this as written with one change (olive oil instead of veg) and the pretzels were great!  Do not skip the baking soda water dip, it is what really makes the pretzel and adds the flavor.  I also made two pretzel dogs (like the mall places) just wrapped the rope around a slightly warmed hot dog.  They were good, just make sure the rope is thin or it overpowers the dog.  Thanks for sharing this Christa!!

SAVANNAH0410

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these tonight and they came out good! I followed the advice of the previous reviewers and only added a scant 4 cups of flour ( plus a little on the table to knead with) and still had to add a little extra water. I used brown sugar instead of white and a healthy squirt of corn syrup ( I read that it produces a chewier pretzel). I let it rise for almost 2 hours in a warm oven and I am not sure it doubled in volume but it did increase in size.   I didn't feel like rolling out and shaping so I just rolled smallish balls out of it( reduced the temperature and flipped them over when the bottoms were getting really brown)..For the baking soda bath I just kept it in a small pot on a very low flame and added about six pieces at a time, I removed them with a slotted spoon ( shaking off excess water) and baked on parchment paper ( I didn't have any problem with the pooling of water or an off taste as mentioned in another review).  Brushed these with an ample amount melted butter when they came out and they taste good and look beautiful. Thanks!

This recipe is so awesome. The baking soda wash sounded kinda tricky, but the whole thing was so easy to follow and the pretzels were SO GOOD. They had that great authentic pretzel taste.

I made them on Valentine's day for my boyfriend (with a matching card, haha) and he loved them. I do agree with other reviewers on using just 4 cups of flour and I turned my oven down to 400 degrees. 8 minutes was the perfect baking time. I sprinkled some with cinnamon sugar -- so yummy!

text:
We have been trying to find an at-home recipe for pretzels that taste like Auntie Anne's.  This is it!!  I would give these 10 stars for taste if I could!!  I made 2 batches for my daughter's birthday party and everyone loved them!!  We did some regular, some with parmesan and garlic on them, and some dipped in butter and cinnamon sugar after cooking.  Delicious!!   This makes a lot and I only used the first batch at the party, so the other sat all afternoon and I made them this evening.  They were a little bit chewier than the 'fresh' batch, but still wonderful!
I did give 5 stars because they were so awesome, but 5 c of flour is too much!!  I only used 4 c and still had to add a little more liquid.  
We loved them and will be making them on a regular basis!! 
Thank you, Christa Rose!!!!

text:
So easy to make!  Added 3.5 C flour like one suggested & added add'l .5 C while kneading.  More flour didn't seem necessary this time.  Baked 6 on 1st pan at 450 for 8mins.  Was real good but bottoms & edges got crunchy & very brown.  Reduced 2nd pan to 410 for 8mins, a bit doughy but not uncooked.  Wasn't bad but next time will need to try in-between.  SO GOOD!  All 3 girls loved them plain!  (Be careful, didn't need lots of salt to make delicious!)

text:
These pretzels are wonderful! I did what another reviewer suggested--substitute butter for the oil and use less flour. One further suggestion from me: there is no reason to make so much baking soda bath... I ended up throwing away most of it. I will only be making half of the bath in the future. Oh, and I put the dough in the oven at 150 for two hours during the rising process. That seemed to work quite well. Enjoy!

Let me start by saying that I consider myself a chef before a baker because I don't like to measure things.  That being said, I always follow t a recipe to the "T" the first time I make it, and this recipe is great.  I followed exactly as directed and my pretzels came out just fine.  I did have to add a little bit of water because the dough was a bit dry (thanks for the previous tips and next time I may cut 1 cup of the flour) but that is to be expected when making a dough product.  Great recipe Christa Rose!  Thanks for sharing and I can't wait to try playing around with all the varieties that can be done with this recipe.

userID:
5414961
Display Name:
ldymcbth
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
15
favoritesCount:
29
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used my breadmaker to make the dough and these were the easiest soft pretzels ever!  I threw all of the ingredients in the breadmaker (I used only 4 cups of flour as others recommended & I used 2 tsp of breadmaker yeast).  I had to leave the house while the breadmaker was doing the work so I actually didn't get back until about 4 hours after the dough would have been finished.  I was worried that it would have more than tripled in size but I came home and the dough was perfect!  I formed the dough into about 24" ropes and then twisted them into pretzels.  Then I dipped them into the simmering baking soda & water, blotted them on a paper towel, placed them on a cookie sheet, brushed with melted butter and sprinkled with salt.  I baked at 400 degrees for 8 minutes and brushed them with melted butter again as they came out of the oven.  I took them to a neighbor's for a party and they were a huge hit!  I will definitely be making these again.

Great recipe tasted identical to Aunt Annie's pretzels! My one and only issue was that I could not stretch my dough out long enough to make a large pretzel. I had to double the amount of dough when shaping the pretzels so I only ended up with six large yummy pretzels as appose to the twelve the recipe says it makes. I also only used 4c of flour and as suggested by another review and I let my dough rise in the oven (the oven was off) only with the oven light on and covered by a damp towel. All and all these pretzels are fabulous!

text:
These were very simple to make, however, it was too dry with the amount of water stated in the recipe. I did have to add 5 more tablespoons of water to make it pliable to work with.  One batch I added poppy seeds to the flour before added the liquid. Those were good. The next ones I'd like to try with dried minced onions. The only problem I had was the bake time/heat seemed to be off (which may be my oven but I don't have problems with my regular recipes)  They got brown very fast but where the dough layers are thick from twisting remained quite doughy in places. I reduced the temp 25 degrees and increased the bake time 5 minutes and that seemed to correct the issue.  Family loved these and I will be making them over and over. I've had requests for these for poker night and bowling league snacks lol.

text:
450 degrees, even 425 is definitely too hot.  400 degrees probably would have been best to prevent darkening.  When you put the pretzels in the acid solution, wait to remove then until they rise.  For the yeast I used one packet (.25 oz) of the active dry yeast and it seemed to work.  Line  your cooking pan with heavy duty foil and spray with Pam for easy clean up. I also brushed the tops with Salted butter after removing from oven.  I used to make the kind with Lye, and these are very similar to my old recipe.

These pretzels were really fun and easy to make.  My kids loved them and ate them as a snack.  I made them according to the directions and they came out really well. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I wish I could give this recipe more than 5 stars!  It was just sweet enough, just salty enough and just buttery enough--the perfect pretzel really.  Like others, I reduced the flour to 4 cups.  I started out with 3 1/2 cups in the sugar/flour/salt mix and then added another half cup as I was kneading the dough, which helped to keep it from sticking.  I used salted butter instead of oil and reduced the salt slightly.  I put the dough in a stainless steel bowl sprayed with cooking spray and then sprayed the top of the dough and placed it in the oven with the light on for an hour, covered with a damp cloth to prevent a dry shell on it.  I also reduced the oven temp to 400, and in 8 minutes the pretzels came out perfect inside and out!  I used unsalted butter to spread on them.  I made 12 of them, and my boyfriend and I gobbled up 9 of them in short order!  This is a very simple and delicious recipe...my favorite kind!  No more mall pretzels for me! Thanks for sharing!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent pretzels!  I used a little less flour than called for and still had to add several tablespoons of water.  Still, it's important to be aware that the humidity where you live can affect the dough, and it's drier today than usual here.  I used my new Kitchen Aid mixer with the dough hook for this (I've made pretzels/bread by hand and in the bread machine, but never in a mixer) and it was a perfect dough after about 5 minutes of mixing.  These are extremely easy and they turn out very well.  I don't think you need as much water or baking soda for the baking soda bath though--a shallow bowl of water with a tbsp or so of baking soda should be enough.  I usually dip pretzels one by one anyway, which is what I did today.  I didn't bother with butter after baking--after dipping in the baking soda bath, I sprinkled half of the pretzels with kosher salt and with the other half I dipped in a mixture of cinnamon and sugar.  Nice taste without all the butter, which I don't think you need anyway.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I made these today after seeing the recipe on the front page a few days ago.  I was so hopeful, but they just didn't turn out for me.  I had the same problems as many other low-star reviewers.  They are very bread-like, not pretzel-like at all.  They have a very small hint of pretzel taste, but otherwise it just tastes like white bread.  I followed the recipe exactly, but did lower the oven temperature to 425 and baked them for 9 or so minutes.  They did cook properly at these temperatures, and weren't doughy in the center as others reported.  The bottoms did not burn, but were much darker than the top and stuck to the baking sheet.  I also had a lot of problems with the dough as others reported.  It absolutely was completely dry and flaky.  I had to add at least 5 tablespoons of water just to make the dough managable (which it still wasn't, but at least it stuck together).  Even then, it was very tough and hard to knead and work with.  My arms and hands were aching!  I let it sit and rise for an hour in the oven with a warm towel covering it, and it made it easier to work with once I was ready to form the pretzels.  They weren't that difficult to roll out; probably the easiest part of the process.  All in all, these didn't turn out.  I didn't bother making all of the pretzels once I tasted the first few that I baked.  Totally disappointed.

userID:
3596192
Display Name:
cschmidt
isPro:

followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These pretzels are amazing. I have made them 3 or 4 times now doubling the recipe the last 2 times. Like other reviewers I made the following changes: I used 4 cups of flour instead of 5 (every time I have to add a couple tablespoons of water to the dough during the kneading process). I also use a little less than the ½ cup sugar, just a personal preference.  I use my mixer for the kneading process with bread hooks and it works fine. I let rise in a cool oven with a damp cloth over the bowl and the oven light on (works for all types of breads). After dipping in the baking soda solution I dab the dough on a paper towel to get the excess water off and place them on wax paper that I spray with cooking spray. I have never had a problem with them sticking. I do not brush with butter or salt at this point. I bake at 400 degrees for 8 minutes or so. The best thing I’ve found out is to under cook the ones we’re not going to eat just a little. I then put those into plastic bags in the freezer. Then I can randomly take some out to thaw, throw them in the toaster oven or regular over for a few minutes dip in butter and top with whatever we feel like that day. This way you can make a bunch and they don’t go bad!  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
These pretzels were great!  I actually made 'pretzel bites' out of them--like the ones you get served in a cup at the mall.  After I rolled them out, I cut them about an ench long with a pastry cutter.  I dipped them in the soda solution, added kosher salt to some of them, and then baked them for about 6 minutes.  When they came out I dipped them in melted butter.  For the ones without salt, I threw them into a ziploc bag full of cinnamon/sugar and fully coated them with sweetness.  These probably took longer to make than big pretzels, but we haven't stopped poppin' them into our mouths ever since!

text:
These pretzels are amazing, and they do taste remarkably like the ones you buy at the mall- only better!  They are very simple to make, and truly do smell buttery as they are baking, even though they have no butter in or on them until they come OUT of the oven!  I sprinkled them with coarse sea salt before putting them in the oven and brushed the tops with butter as soon as they were done. I also followed another reviewer's suggestion and only used 4 C of flour, which was perfect.  My son was so excited to have one of these after school that he told me "You're the best Mom in the world!" (He's 6 :) This is a new regular in our house!

how i made 'perfect browning': alter&add. reduced water to 3 cups; after dipping, silicone brush on 'lightly,lightly' egg white with tiny sprinkle of more soda. baked on buttered parchment paper. flour: 4 cups, 1and1/3 whole wheat, the rest all purpose. also, melt a stick and a half of light butter in oven and dip each whole pretzel in it, both sides. this really made them 100% better; i just whoofed 3. perfect-0 :)

country:
None
text:
Not only was this recipe a cinch to make, but the pretzels are so good!  I wish I had made more of them.  Since this was my first time making pretzels, I cut the recipe in half and only made six.  I followed the directions almost exactly, however, I cooked them at 425 degrees and they cooked in about 4-5 minutes.  I suggest standing there and watching them until they look brown enough.  Anyway, the pretzels were a little large and I could only fit four on a baking sheet.  I dipped the remaining two into the water/baking soda mixture and left them on a different baking sheet until the first batch was done.  I mention this because I worried that they would be ruined by sitting out after being dipped in water.  No need to worry!  They turned out great!  After they came out of the oven, I brushed them with butter and then sprinkled with regular table salt.  Perfect!  This is a really good recipe to do with your kids...my young daughter had a blast!  Thank you for a great recipe!
*UPDATE* I made these for the second time this past weekend and made an interesting discovery.  I thought some of my pretzels from my first batch were too crunchy and so this time around I made my dough ropes thicker.  The pretzels tasted great, but they were much softer and more like rolls than pretzels.  I think the thinner ropes are better because they make a crunchy outside and a chewy inside - just as they should be.

userID:
2467897
Display Name:
cuisine_queen
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Our family used to go to Life Action Family Camp in Michigan every summer. My kids loved Pretzel Night where all the families would gather to take hunks of dough and shape, dunk, bake and eat until we were stuffed. I've tried many times to replicate the recipe at home but never could do it. In a winter slump, the kids were begging for summer and pretzels. I can't make it summer time, but I can cook! I decided to give the pretzel thing another go with this recipe. It was a BIG hit! I used 2 1/2 c. fresh ground spelt flour and 2 1/2 c. all purpose flour. I put all the dry ingredients including the yeast into the Bosch mixer. I turned it on and drizzled in the oil and then added the HOT water until the dough was sticky. I let the Bosch do it's magic on speed 1 until the dough was a shiny soft ball (about 9 minutes). I turned the machine off and let it sit with the lid on for an hour. It rose beautifully! I could tell at that point that this recipe was a keeper because the dough was so elastic and silky. We shaped them and dunked them in the water/soda mixture. (Thank you mose for the explanation. In the past I skipped this step because I couldn't figure out why it was necessary!) I cooked them at about 425 degrees for 6 to 7 minutes. You really want to keep an eye on them because they'll burn fast. These turned out to be the best pretzels we ever made. The kids requested we make some more tonight. Weather Forcast: Snow!

text:
This was my first attempt at making pretzels for my super bowl party.  I followed the advice of other reviewers and used 3 ½ cups of flour.  I don’t know where in the world 5 cups of flour are coming from but do yourself a favor and start with 3 ¼.  You can always add flour but can not take it away.  Other than that these were really tasty and easy to make and I had fun making them.  I will definitely make these again.  Now all I need to find is a mustard dipping sauce to make them perfect.

text:
Great recipe!! I tried this one out of the 3 or so others and I was not disappointed! My tweaks for the recipe: used 4 cups flour; only used 2 cups water and 1/4 cup baking soda for the "bath" and I put it in a saucepan to keep it warmed/to dissolve the baking soda; used 1 tbsp butter instead of oil; used 1/4 cup sugar instead of 1/2. I also did the egg wash step before they went into the oven. I have a gas oven and had to reduce cooking time to 4.5-5 miniutes so they were nice and soft. No complaints & husband loves them! Thanks for the recipe :)

text:
I didn't follow these directions exactly. The dough was mixed and kneaded in a bread machine (90 minutes). Then I rolled out the pretzels and let them rise for an hour. After that I boiled the water and baking soda for a 1 minute bath. The boiling bath gave them a tougher outer shell (like a bagel). In the end they came out great. We even had enough dough for 16. So we made a braided strand and a roll for practice.

These are amazing. VERY EASY TO MAKE! In fact I just had surgery 4 days ago on my hand, so I was able to make these one handed!! (I had some issues when it came to rolling them out lol) I followed the recipe exactly as its stated. It doesn't say how long to make the rope, but my suggestion is more than 8-10" which is how long I made mine. I would suggest a very thin rope about 20" long. Don't be afraid, it raises in the oven. That's my next suggestion, SPACE THEM OUT! To get a good even color on them make sure you make them in batches. 

Overall, amazing turn out!!

Display Name:
Valeria
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1041281.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yes, these pretzels came out absolutely astonishing. And the most wonderful thing is that I didn't had any hard time with them at all. I followed Wayne Gisslen's advise from his "Professional baking" that active dry yeast must be rehydrated in 4 times its weight of warm water. So I dissolved 4 tsps (0,5 oz/15 g) of yeast and 1 tsp of sugar in 2 oz (60 ml) of water. And later I just added separately the yeast mix and remaining water (8 oz/235 ml) in the flour mix. 4 cups of flour were more than enough. I kneaded it with a dough hook on the 2nd speed for 10 min. I let it rise for 1 hour, punched down and let it relax on the bench 20 more minutes.  After I had made up pretzels and soaked them in soda bath, I sprinkled half of them with poppy seeds and salt, and another half with sesames and salt. Baked every batch only for 8 min. Then covered them with melted butter. Pretzels are the best just after the baking, though they are very good the next day even without any air-tight package. 
I have tried to bake pretzels on parchment paper, silicone mat and just on the oiled cookie sheet. And I can say: never ever bake them on oiled cookie sheets (!!!) They will stick anyway and you'll eat pretzels without their bottoms.
The next time I'll try to half the amount of sugar in the dough.

These were soooo good!  I followed the recipe as is but then simmered the pretzels for about 10 seconds each in the baking soda/water mixture.  I turned the oven on 400 degrees and I am glad I did because they were dark at that temperature.  I can't even imagine them any higher. I brushed butter on them after they came out of the oven and left some like that, some with mustard, and some with cinnamon sugar.  They were all so good! They didn't need any salt because of all the salt in the recipe, baking soda is salty and I used salted butter. I will definitely make these again and again!

country:
None
text:
I've made these five times now with my grandchildren (ages 4,5,6).  It is an easy recipe, fun to make into shapes, and delicious to eat.  We made some with salt and most plain and brushed with butter when they came out of the oven.  My only constructive comment deals with the baking soda wash.  We used MUCH less than the 1/2 cup of baking soda recipe calls for and you don't need 4 cups water!   I dissolved 2 TEASPOONS in about 1 cup water (in the microwave) and then put the solution in a flat dish.  I dipped the pretzels in the solution (rather than letting the children) and it worked out fine.  You do not need to waste all that baking soda.   You need the solution to make them brown, so they look like pretzels, but you do not need a lot.  We tried brushing the solution on the pretzels (and the children could do that) but the color looked best by dipping.   A WONDERFUL KITCHEN PROJECT.... will do again, many times, I'm sure.

country:
None
text:
This is a great pretzel recipe!  The baking soda solution is a MUST.  If you do not use it, the pretzels would just be salty pretzel-shaped bread. I changed a few things, for the baking soda solution, I only use 1/4 cup of baking soda and two cups of water. Also, I keep the solution in a small pan on the stove and have it barely simmer. For the pretzel itself, I brush it with butter before putting it in the oven, and brush it AGAIN with butter after it comes out, then sprinkle it with kosher salt. But if you use pretzel salt, it is better to put it on the pretzels before you put them in the oven, just because that helps the salt stick better. FYI- just to let you guys know.... I'M TWELVE. Shocker huh?

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe made good tasting pretzels, but there are some modifications that need to be made.

First off, don't bother proofing the yeast. Just mix the yeast into the flour and other dry ingredients and add the water. Second, 2 packets of yeast equals 4 1/2 tsp. If you are using packets, don't measure, just add two packets. Third, 5 cups of flour is WAY too much for 1 1/4 cups of liquid. Mix 3 cups of flour with the other dry ingredients, add the water and mix. Then slowly add enough flour to make a stiff dough. You will not need 5 cups of flour.

text:
I made these pretzels and they were gone the next day. I had to add more water( the two tablespoons, plus about two more)and then more floor to maintain the dough texture.I let the dough rise by filling a bowl of hot water, and placing the dough on the bowl in the microwave. I decided to alternate the flavors and made half plain, and the other half sugared. For the sugared, I used a homemade caramel recipe( got from a caramel popcorn recipe) and stuffed two with trail mix. I let them cook at the given temperature, then basted them, and put them in the oven at 350 degrees for extra browning. A day later, I reheated some in the oven( basted them with butter, and caramel again) and made a nacho cheese mixture( milk,two slice American cheese, one slice pepper-jack) and got rave reviews from my guests. This is a great recipe and I will definitely be making more. This was a easy recipe to follow and was great for snacking.

text:
Wow, these are good!  I made exactly as stated, I used a jelly roll pan with melted butter in the bottom, and after the baking soda/hot water bath I put them on the pan top side down to get some butter, then flipped them back onto their backs, sprinkled the salt and baked.  Wow!!  I burned my tongue eating one right out of the oven, but it was so worth it!!  Excellent recipe!

By the way, April 26 (today!) is National Pretzel Day, so it was imperative that we had these today! :-)

country:
None
text:
excellent!  Made two batches.  Sub'd applesauce for oil and cooking spray for butter both batches.  They are still outstanding without adding artery-clogging fat to them via butter and oil.  

Second batch, made the following add'l modific for health reasons:  whole wheat flour only, subtract 3 T sugar from 1/2 c called for.  Very good again, both plain and with honey drizzled on top.  

Read many reviews before making.  Used 4c flour instead of 5c.  400F oven for 8 min instead of 450F.  Be sure to roll them out to 20-24 inches.  That seems long, but is necessary since they proof-out after shaping and before baking.  (For first-timers:  yes, baking soda bath is necessary for true pretzel taste.)

text:
I halved this recipe and made them last night.  I followed the directions for the proportions and they were exactly right.  I let the dough rise with a damp hand towel over it instead of plastic wrap so that it stayed moist.  When my first rise was finished, I was busy doing other things, so I punched it down and let it rise again before using it.  I made half of these cinnamon sugar and half of them salt.  I used COURSE ground KOSHER salt, which is what pretzels should probably have (think the stuff in the Super Pretzel box).  The salt ones are WAY better than the others, so next time I will stick with those.  I did brush hot butter on them before coating them in the salt, but they are so delicious that way!!!

I found this recipe last weekend & finally made them today. I halved the recipe as I made bread yesterday & didn't need all of that bread in the house. My husband & I devoured 4 of them in less then 10 minutes. I did need to add extra water to the dough. I also wish I had read more reviews before making. I would have taken the tip to not use flour to roll the ropes & to wet my hands to roll them. I couldn't get the dough ropes long enough, so we had super fat small pretzels. I baked at 415, but had to increase baking time to 11 minutes. That's probably just my oven though. I made them all with salt. My husband said these would be great with cinnamon sugar. He has more of a sweet tooth then me. I will definitly make a full batch the next time I make these.

text:
Perfect! I used only 4 cups flour, and used half bread flour, half all purpose. I used only 1 TB sugar since I hate savory things to be too sweet, and used butter instead of oil. Otherwise I did everything the same. I dipped them in butter after I took them out of the oven, and then dipped half in cinnamon sugar and half I sprinkled with sea salt. To DIE for! Seriously. To up the ante even more I made a cheese sauce with a cup of milk, 2 TB flour, a cup of shredded sharp cheddar cheese, and a bit of powdered cheddar cheese I ordered from nutsonline. In another dish I melted 4  ounces of dark chocolate with a TB of butter and 1/4 c sugar to make a chocolate sauce for the sweet pretzels. This was a meal in and of itself, and it was the best meal ever! My skeptical husband who doesn't even like pretzels had to apologize for doubting that these would be good! Yay!

text:
sea salt is the absolute best thing to top them with (but be sure to use kosher salt in the dough),
 
 
 Excellent recipe! I've found it is best to add 3.5 cups of flour and slowly mix in the final half cup as I'm kneading the dough
The baking soda water bath is key. Also I had such a hard time using flour to roll the pretzels and found a how-to video from Auntie Anne's pretzel company online and it suggested not using flour while rolling the pretzels and it worked! I took the advice of other reviewers and only used 4 cups of flour. And use a clean towel or a few sheets of papertowel for blotting excess water after dipping pretzels--also on the how-to video. And so I made these soooo many different ways, too! Salt, Cinnamon and sugar, cinnamon raisin, apple cinnamon

text:
I'd never made pretzels before in my life, so I didn't know what to expect from this recipe. I was pleasantly surprised at how easy it was...aside from having a heck of a time getting them rolled out long enough to make them look like pretzels! I have now bookmarked AND saved this recipe to my recipe box. They are SO delicious! I had read the reviews before making them, so I used a bit less flour than it calls for, and rather than using vegetable oil or melted butter, I used garlic olive oil. I also dipped the pretzels in melted butter after baking them, and then sprinkled the kosher salt on them. We are eating them as we speak, and they are amazing. No more going to the mall and spending $5 on a single pretzel! :D

text:
i used whole wheat, with olive oil. i needed three times the oil to get the consistency i wanted. tip for when rolling: divide equally into however many pretzels you want, if the balls are too sticky sprinkle very little flour on them. if they are not rolling correctly add a little oil to your hands when rolling them out. its easier on a clean counter. (without flour) lastly the baking soda bath is a must, it browned my whole wheat flour beautifully!!!!

text:
THE BEST!  I have tried other recipes on this site that "claim" to taste like a particular restaurant or chain - but these truly do taste just as good - even BETTER.  I am a baker (I even make wedding cakes) - so I'm picky.  These are phenomenal. I dipped the tops in melted butter then pressed in a bowl of cinnamon sugar.  I think I may like these even better than my homemade cinnamon rolls.  Delicious.  Do not skip the baking soda water dip - crucial to the authentic pretzel taste.

country:
None
text:
I have baked my entire life and this seemed like the easiest of recipes for a pretzel. There was no boiling beforehand - so this was a short cut, so to speak.
 
I should have known better.  They came out biscuit like on the inside and you have to watch the temperature to keep the bottoms from burning but still allow the tops to brown.
 
I always read the reviews and didn't see anything I should've done differently.  They aren't eve close to a mall pretzel. 
 
And if you are wondering why so many of the 174 pics are of fat, clumpy pretzels?  It takes a long time to roll them to get them thin and long enough to make it appear like "Auntie Em's" pretzels.
 
We did it, but still - biscuit like interior and crunchy exterior. Gross.

Display Name:
It's A New Day
isPro:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are very good and definitely taste like the ones from the mall.  I used one cup of sourdough starter for one cup of the water, adding the rest of the warm water and the yeast and sugar to foam up as directed.  It did!  Meantime I measured out 2 cups of bread flour and 1 cup of whole wheat in a bowl, thinking that I would then add 2 cups of ap flour after I added the yeast mixture.  Well that didn't happen.  That 3 cups of flour was already too much and I had to add about 1 T of water to get it to come together.  I really cannot make any bread products with all white flour but I've never had such a deficit in the amount called for and the amount I used.  I ran out of time at that point and had to put the dough in the refrigerator until the next morning when I took it out and put it in a cold oven with the light on.  It sat there for about 4 hours which was a little too long.  The dough was hard to shape and stretch; it was very elastic.  The end results did not look like pretzels even though I tried.  I rubbed a stick of butter over the tops as soon as they came out of the oven and sprinkled with kosher salt.  They are very tasty and did have a slight sourdough taste (but that will only happen if you use sourdough starter as I did).  I will be making these again, hopefully all in one day to see if the dough acts any better.  Note:  these did not last 24 hours in my house.  DD asked that I make them again when I have sourdough starter to use, which will be every 5 days!

I would give these 3 1/2 stars, not 3.  These were easy to make.  kind of skimpy on the size, so I remade and made 6 instead of 12.  The ONLY difference I did was used actual pretzel salt instead of kosher.  These are good pretzels, however they're not the best.  I'm still looking for a recipe that I adore, and unfortunately these aren't it.  now I WILL make these again, and probably use the dough recipe to make cinnamon rolls (minus the dipping in the brine).  

All in all, I'd recommend them (if asked for a pretzel recipe), but not highly.

text:
This was my very 1st time making pretzels!  I used this recipe and the "Soft Giant Pretzels" recipe also on this site to compare.  This was the winner!  It had the right color and the best overall flavor by far!!  With that said, I'm giving it 3 stars because I did have some issues.  Next time I will use 4 cups of flour for a more moist dough which will be easier to roll out.  I will bake on a higher rack to not have burnt bottoms.  I will likely bake at 400 degrees instead of 450. I will really make sure all the pretzels have a nice rich brown color b/f I take them out of the oven.  And, I will eat less of the finished product so I don't feel so sick!

text:
These were great.  The only thing I did differently from the recipe was to bake at 430 degrees for 9 minutes.
Also, I found rolling out the dough on a floured surface didn't work too well for me.  It was easier to take the divided piece of dough, kind of lightly coat my hands in oil, then roll out the dough by hand or by rolling directly on the counter top with no flour.  The flour seemed to make it less elastic.
Regardless, they tasted fantastic - exactly what I was craving.  They were gone in seconds - I'll be making some up to freeze soon.

text:
Yum!!  We all agreed that these are better than Auntie Anne's.  The pretzels are slightly sweet, and so tasty.  I used a little over 4 cups of flour and had to add about a tablespoon of water to get a good consistency.  Rise time was about an hour in the warming drawer.  Recipe says to turn out onto lightly floured surface and roll into ropes.  This didn't work for me.  The flour prevented the dough from rolling and all it would do was slide on the counter.  I brushed the flour off and moistened my hands a little as needed and then they rolled out pretty easily.  I can't wait to try these again with other flavors, like cinnamon sugar or glazed!!

So, I followed the recipe exactly, except that I halved it (I only had one packet of yeast on hand) and lowered the cook temp and baked for an extra two min.

text:
This is such a great recipe!!!  I did the dough in my bread machine on the dough cycle.  I did the yeast, sugar and water right in the bread machine pan and let it set per the recipe till it was creamy/foamy.  Then I added the oil. Then the flour and sugar. And last of all the salt (keeping the salt and yeast furthest away from each other).  The dough cycle ran, I rolled them out, dunked them in the soda/water and baked them.  So easy.  And so yummy!!  I need to perfect my rolling skills and get them to stretch out a bit more, but even thick and chunky they were good!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Pretty good, needed some adjustments.  After one of my pretzels started to "melt" in the baking soda solution, I cut the baking soda to 1/3 of a cup, and combined it with 6 c. water on the stove. Once it came to a boil, I dropped in each pretzel individually until the outside started to solidify, and then scooped it out using a spatula.   When they came out of the oven, they were certainly tasty but the underside was still a bit goopy and uncooked, though the tops were done. If I did it again, I'd drop the temperature to 375-390 and stick them in there for 15-20 min, so they were more evenly cooked.

I made the recipe almost exactly as is, but I feel there should be some changes made. Next time I will use less flour as I had to add a few Tbs. of water because my dough was so dry. I think this is still a little hot. The underside of my pretzels were a little dark for my taste. I will definitely lower to around 400 degrees next time.  Even though they were slightly dense they were still very tasty!

text:
Excellent recipe!  I read the other reviews and made adjustments as follows: - used 4 cups flour instead of 5 - used butter in place of oil - rolled (by hand & with roller) thin and long - reduced oven temp to 400  - cooked for 7 minutes instead of 8  - brushed/dumped some butter on them right out of the oven  The result was amazing and I was upset that I hadn't made more.  Myself and two friends had these finished in no time.  We had a small one left over that somehow sat out all night long on the counter...it was no longer a "soft" pretzel by the next day but still ridiculously good!  In addition to making the obvious pretzel shape I also made pretzel sticks & pretzel braids/twists...very fun & delicious!

userID:
1577818
Display Name:
LemonLush
isPro:
False
followersCount:
149

madeRecipesCount:
128
favoritesCount:
107
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/630508.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were pretty good but the dough is far too dry.  My recipe calls for 2.5 cups of bread flour and 7/8 to 1 cup of warm water (it makes 8 pretzels, not 12).  My recipe doesn't use ANY fats or oils in the dough and I brush on unsalted butter, not dip them.  I only use 3 TBS butter and the unsalted butter doesn't add excess salt if you're using Kosher salt to the tops.  Also, my recipe doesn't have nearly this much sugar.  These aren't sweet rolls, they are pretzels!!!  I use bread flour for mine and the pretzels are more authentic in my opinion.  I also let my dough rise on the counter in a plastic zip lock bag for 30 minutes.  Just flour your dough and zip it almost all the way.  That's all the rise they need.  Any more and they expand too much.  Roll your ropes out very thin and long.. and only let them rise until just doubled before dipping in the water/soda mix.  Make sure your water and soda are mixed really well, otherwise you'll end up with splotchy looking pretzels.

text:
These were truly excellent, with a few tweaks.  In place of the active dry yeast, I used 3 tsp of instant yeast, mixed with the dry ingredients.  I used 2 cups all-purpose & 2 cups whole-wheat flour (4 cups total), and I substituted vegetable oil for light olive oil.  Unfortunately I found that the other reviewers were incorrect about adjusting the oven temp - I tried 10 minutes on 415 degrees but my pretzels were not done in the middle.  Next time I'll try what the recipe recommended - 8 minutes at 450 degrees - and hope for the best!

text:
I found the recipe to have a hint of sweentness to it but I expected it because of Christa's description.  I too agree with other reviews that 5 cups of flour is too much to add to the dough while mixing.  I believe I used about 4 cups and then kneaded the other cup into it.  I also had to add 3 Tbls water to the mix.  I took the suggestion from others and coated all in butter spray after removing from oven and then used koesher salt on half and cinnamon and sugar on the other half hoping for a breakfast treat.  Kids thought I used too much salt and thought it was weird I told them to dip it in mustard.  One liked it and one didn't (personal preference I guess). Overall would use this recipe again.  I did heat the water and baking soda in a pan like another reveiwer suggested to keep the water warm because you have so many to dip.  One thing I will keep in mind when making again is to make the strips very thin because ours baked together and didn't really keep the pretzel shape with the normal circle openings.  The taste I would give a 5 only giving a 4 because I followed the recipe exactly and 5 cups flour was too much to add to the mix.  Overall - good pretzel recipe.  Husband said tastes like a pretzel, which was a compliment!  I think the kids will like the breakfast version better with the cinnamon and sugar.  I loved them!
