https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/278817.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These taste really yummy. The first time I made these, I did a variety of toppings to try to find the best tasting ones: salted, unsalted, butter, no butter, etc. Best combination: Salted, no butter. I find they taste buttery all on their own, without adding any extra butter. They do go brown fast, but its not like they are burning; it's just the baking soda mixture causing them to brown a little bit faster. The ones that manage to make it throught the night end up going soggy and the salt disintegrates, but warming  them in the microwave makes it all better. The method is a little bit strange. When making yeast breads, you should only add some of the flour and make a kind of paste (With this recipe, only add 2 cups to start)  and mix the "paste" thoroughly for a few minutes, to start forming gluten. Then gradually add the remaining flour until the dough pulls away from the sides of the bowl. Turn out and knead until smooth and no longer sticky, adding flour as needed. I use this recipe to make 8 giant pretzels, baking 4 at a time and shaping the remaining dough while the first 4 are in the oven.

text:
I just made these, except i used beer instead of water, and instant yeast instead of active dry. They're delicious, but next time i will do the following tweaks:  use stout instead of lager. Was looking for a more pronounced flavor and the lager just didn't satisfy. i ended up using a whole bottle of lager for 5 cups of flour. (if you use beer, heat it up in your microwave before using it)  keep the pretzel in the hot soda solution for around 25 seconds instead of just 10 to 15 seconds so the crust will gelatinize a bit more.  remember to spray parchment with oil. The pretzels stuck to the parchment paper, but not my silpat.  use 4 cups of flour to start instead of all 5.. or use more beer. haha!  I also topped mine with salt and garlic powder, then brushed with garlic butter right out of the oven. Yummy, and very filling!

text:
It took a couple tries (user error) but these pretzels are absolutely amazing and identical to mall pretzels. Well worth all the effort!  FLOUR: I put in 2 1/2C of flour to start, then gradually put in another cup or so while kneading.  I used a total of 3 3/4C flour.  KNEADING: I kneaded this for about 8 minutes in my KitchenAid Artisan mixer.  WATER: My water was 110F degrees when proofing the yeast.  BAKING: The pretzels were perfect at 9 minutes on a baking stone.

Unlike others I haven't had a single problem with the recipe.  I follow it exactly and have great results.  I do lower my oven temp to 425 as my oven tends to run high. Also, don't forget about making sticks instead of full pretzels.  I think the full size pretzels are too much for my younger kids to snack on.

text:
Very good! This was my first "bread making" experience - I was scared b/c I  have never kneaded dough before, but I looked it up on YouTube and was sure to keep my water between 110-115 degrees for the yeast. Don't be scared if you've never done it before, you can do it!!!  Just be aware. Let my bread proof almost 2 hrs (left the house for a while) and had to use 1 cup of wholewheat flour (ran out of AP flour). I also followed the suggestion and used butter instead of oil. The texture of these were amazing, but be sure to roll out your strips of dough quite thin...i didn't and mine were quite Fat little things instead of the traditional size!!! Also,...USE LESS FLOUR! Do not use 5 cups...Add 4, then "eyeball" the rest. Don't forget your CAN add water if the mixture is too dry (I did and still emptied out excess flour).  Still tasted GREAT! Loved them. A+++ *idea* anybody thought about coating them in garlic and butter?

text:
Unbelievable!  Where I live, there are no mall pretzel places.  About twice a year, I travel to where there IS one, and it's ALWAYS the first thing I have when I get there.  These, in my opinion, are SO MUCH BETTER!!  Light and fluffy on the inside, thin crispy shell...so good.  I used 4.5 cups of flour and still had to add a bit of water.  The dough was dense, but easily managable.  I rolled it out on the unfloured countertop easily.  I made 6 regular pretzel shaped ones and the rest were made into pretzel bites that I divided into parmesan and garlic (dipped in butter after the baking soda bath and then in parmesan cheese and garlic powder) and the rest brushed with butter and sprinkled with coarse salt.  I made a nacho cheese sauce, and it was utterly divine with the salted ones.  This will be made regularly in my house, for sure.

text:
These are the BEST! I didn't change a thing and they were perfect! Everyone in my family LOVED them! The 7year old even helped me make them. The CHEESE SAUCE RECIPE that I used to dip these in was great too! 2.CUPS BUTTER   2.TBL FLOUR   1.TSP SALT    1. CUP MILK   1.CUP SHREDDED CHEDDAR CHEESE     1. tsp PREPARED MUSTARD.  DIRECTIONS: MELT BUTTER IN SAUCEPAN. MIX IN FLOUR AND SALT. SLOWLY POUR IN MILK AND COOK OVER MED. HEAT UNTIL MIXTURE IS THICKENED. STIR IN CHEDDAR CHEESE AND MUSTARD. MIX UNTIL SMOOTH. REMOVE FROM HEAT AND SERVE HOT/WARM.  ADD SALT AND PEPPER TO TASTE ENJOY! GOD BE WITH YOU!

text:
I've made these pretzels 3 times now.  The first two times, the only adjustment I made was to lower the temperature a bit. These pretzels are phenomenal.  They are my first foray into the whole baking bread/yeast, mixing dough thing and I found the intstructions easy to follow and turned out well!  This last time I tried two things:  pretzel bites instead of big pretzels and substituted 2 cups whole wheat flour.  They came out burned a bit.  I think I should have adjusted my time a bit because there was more surface area to be cooked?  The Whole wheat thing, while healthier, makes them taste a lot more like dinner rolls with lots of butter and salt than pretzels.

text:
I made this with one change.  I didn't have enough white flour so I used 3 1/2 cups of white flour and 1 cup of whole wheat pastry flour.  Worked beautifully.  For future: I would lessen the sugar to 1/4 cup as the dough was a touch too sweet for me.  Double up on the cookie sheets so that the bottom will be thicker to protect the pretzel's bottoms.  Mine got a bit too dark despite putting it on the top rack.  And when they say roll it out real thin, do it pencil thin as this expands ALOT while baking.    But this recipe is a keeper and was delicious!

text:
Made these into pretzel bites for a party and they were gone in minutes!  I mixed the ingredients in reverse (gradually added the flour to the liquids, instead of liquids to flour) like I do with other doughs, so probably ended using about 4 1/4 c. flour.  But very very easy and our kitchen smelled fabulous while they baked!  Thanks for the recipe!

None
text:
These pretzels turned out very well!  I made a  half-batch last night and my husband raved about them and hinted that I should make them again (I'm waiting for the dough to rise right now as I write this).   I did make a couple of adjustments, though:  I reduced the dough to 4 cups, and I used all brown sugar in both the yeast mixture and the flour mixture. This allowed the pretzel to come out soft and chewy, yet not doughy. And DO reduce your baking temperature to 400 to allow the pretzels to bake thoroughly while not scorching the bottoms. Also, be sure to use greased waxed paper or parchment, so that you can easily remove them from the pan. Immediately out of the oven, I brushed them with sweet butter (there's enough salt in there already) and served them warm.  They flew off the plate!

text:
I enjoyed this recipe; it's hard to say that this really tastes like a soft pretzel.  Nevertheless, the flavor is good.  Things to note: only use 4 cups of flour and reserve some of the 4th cup to to use when kneading the dough; turn on the oven to 200 degrees and place the dough in an oiled boil over the back-burner for 1.5 hours; spread butter over the pretzels while the pretzels are cooking in the oven and again when the pretzels come out of the oven, and cook the pretzels in batches at 425F degrees for 10 minutes.  Update: I changed the serving to 4 and I only needed about 1 cup of flour.
Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

userID:
3219749
Display Name:
Melissa Kennedy
isPro:
False
followersCount:

6
favoritesCount:
64
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5597586.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe. I have made three dozen of these now. The first dozen didn't turn out as well. I didn't kneed the dough long enough and it was very hard to work with. It made thick pretzels. I suggest you adhere to the instructions on the kneed time. It helps! The second time I made a double batch. It was great! The dough was easy to work with and fluffy and light. The rolling is always the longest part, but you get a technique down after the first time you do it. My technique was to roll it like a snake in my hands and then once I got it about 8-10 inches long, I would put it on the table and roll as I put pressure on the ends rolling outward to lengthen the dough. I would start in the middle and work my way to the edge. It took a while to roll 24 pretzels, but it was well worth it. The baking soda dip is esential to the process. The first time I made these, I had the oven rack down too low and the bottoms were done before the top. I had to turn them over to get the tops brown. But, the second time I made them, I let them soak in the baking soda mixture for about 3 seconds before taking them out. I cooked the second batch at a slightly lower temperature (it may just be my oven), and I lowered the flour some. I lost count when I was doing the double batch with 10 cups of flour so I think I only used 9. Regardless, they turned out great. I also didn't have any kosher salt. I ate them plain and they were still great. The next batch I am going to make, I am going to try

text:
Soooo Good!!! My kids LOVE these. Found this recipe about 3 weeks ago and have made it 4x's so far.  I do have to decrease the flour to between 4 to 4.5 cups and because my oven cooks super fast and at a higher temp than most, I cook mine at 350 for 8 minutes. They come out perfect each time - brown not burned at the bottom and perfectly chewy in the inside.  When I put them in the baking soda solution I wait until they float before I remove them - maybe 8 seconds.  And as soon as they come out of the oven I brush them with melted butter. YUM.  Oh, and these freeze very well.  Through out the weekdays, I just pull the pretzels out and warm for 30 seconds in the microwave for a great afterschool snack for the kiddos.

text:
Followed the recipe exactly except used my breadmaker on dough setting.  Unlike others, found that 5 cups flour was perfect.  Baked 8 min at 450 and pretzels were very dark on the bottom, edible to adults but not children.  Reduced baking time and temp to 410 and they were golden brown but doughy inside.  My error may have been not rolling out pieces long & skinny enough before shaping into pretzels. Dipping in baking soda solution did not give a true pretzel crust, will try boiling next time.  Despite problems, recipe has potential and the pretzels are all gone (then again, my kids like raw bread dough...)

text:
I followed the recipe precisely and am not pleased with the results. First off, the temp was too high so they browned too quickly on top and the insides were still doughy. Also, 5 cups is WAY too much flour (maybe that's why they were so doughy???).  

Next time, I will use only 4 cups of flour, 1/2 the amount of sugar and decrease the baking temperature to 400 degrees.

The lesson I learned?  Always, ALWAYS read all the reviews first!!!  :)

text:
I thought this recipe was great! And after adding my own toppings they tasted just like the soft pretzels you can get at the mall. I did make a few modifications as per some of the previous reviewers, I only used 4 cups of flour, 1 tsp of salt and 1/4 cup more water than listed in order to keep the dough consistent. As for toppings I used melted butter with ground garlic, parmesan cheese and sesame seeds (which I spread on both before and after they came out of the oven) as one kind and cinnamon and powdered sugar as another. Very delicious, they came out flavourful and not a bit too salty or too sweet as others have mentioned. Will definitely make again.

text:
I used 1 packet (1 gram) of stevia instead of sugar and 4 cups of flour instead of 5.  Used the dough attachment    on my mixer and this came out looking a little dry.  I resisted the urge to add more water as this is a dry bread and letting it rise.  The dough was fighting me when it was time to roll out but wetting my hands with the baking soda mixture resulted in a long easy to weave dough.  Baked it for 10 minutes on a pizza/bread stone and ate this with a sprinkle of powder sugar & cinnamon right out of the oven (yes, i am a carb-a-holic). YUMMY!  Thank you for sharing this easy recipe.

userID:
1469666
Display Name:
T.C.
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe called for either too much flour or too little water, making the dough very dry and difficult to combine into something workable.  Consequently, I had to add more than the one or two tablespoons of water mentioned in the original recipe.  Although the pretzels smelled delicious out of the oven, the end result was very yeasty; I would recommend using, at most, only half the amount of yeast the original recipe calls for.  Moreover, it was difficult to roll out the dough into pretzel shapes that would not immediately shrink into small balls, but the recipe might make good dinner rolls.

4138638
Display Name:
tinanarula

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were really yummy! It is the last of many pretzel recipes that I tried. I finally found "the one". I made the dough in my bread machine on the dough cycle. I started with the yeast proofing  step (in the bread pan) as directed in the  original recipe. Then I added the rest of the sugar, the water, and the oil. I added the flour a little at  a time  as the machine started kneading. I think I added a little less than four cups. I think most of the people who complained about the recipe don't understand that flour in bread is not always the same amount and you need to play with it until it is "right".   Once the dough was the right consistency I left it to run through the dough cycle in the bread machine.   After the cycle was complete I finished the pretzels according to the original recipe. I boiled the pretzels in the baking soda bath. The baking soda bath is essential. The baking soda soak is what causes the pretzels to brown on the outside and still be soft on the inside.  These were almost identical to the overpriced pretzels they sell at the mall,

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe! I was craving Aunt Annie's yesterday, but I didn't feel like leaving the house so I googled soft pretzels and this came up. Really simple!!!!!! Instead of kosher salt, which is the same as regular table salt but the difference is that kosher salt grains are bigger, I used cinnamon sugar. After soaking them in the baking soda water I just rolled the damp dough in the cinnamon sugar before baking. Yummmmmmy! I then made an icing using 8oz cream cheese, 1/2 cup soften butter, 1 teaspoon vanilla extract, and 2 cups confectioner (powdered) sugar! Yummmmmmy It's also good with a cheese sauce that is the popular 16oz velveeta and a can of rotel. :) im fat now haha I could see this being fun for kids to make because playing in the dough was fun. If you are looking for a warm place just turn your stove onto 500 degrees and sit the metal/tin (not plastic because it will melt) on top the stove. :)

text:
These soft pretzels were delicious. I followed the recipe except I used only 4 cups of flour as suggested by other reviews. It worked out perfectly. I boiled the water with the baking soda. Keeping the dough covered with a damp towel is key to being able to elongate the dough without it retracting.  I used cinnamon and sugar and some with just salt for topping before putting them in the oven. When they came out they were brushed with melted butter.  They were soft and buttery and the ones with cinnamon and sugar were amazing. 
Great recipe. I'm going to repeat next weekend!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe. Needs a little tweaking, but the base recipe is good, and very simple.

Having never eaten or made soft pretzels before, I didn't have much to compare to, except the small, crispy pretzels one buys in a bag. But this recipe made it easy. The rolling out was still kind of tedious, but *no* recipe is going to get you out of that. 

My tweaks: *Used more yeast due to the weather. Its too cold here to expect 4tsps to work that well. Increased to 2 tblsp and it worked great. *This recipe calls for too much flour for my elevation. (Then again, nearly EVERY recipe does. :P) So I started with 3 cups of flour, and that was plenty. Another half cup (roughly - put on by small amounts) used for dusting and making the dough non-sticky during kneading and during shaping. I also replaced the oil with butter for better flavour. *Sea Salt instead of kosher.

End result GOOD flavour. I did find the dough was way too sweet for a pretzel. Next time I make them, will probably cut the sugar in half, or down to a tablespoon for the yeast. Also found the bottoms darkened faster than the rest. Lowered temp to 375 and bottoms were still overdone. Next time I might try brushing baking soda wash on, to keep the bottoms clear.

Will retry this recipe with noted changes, though. It was good.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous! I've made these several times and they always turn out scrumptious! I followed the advice of others to use less flour and that's worked well for me. The only other change I make is to use half the amount of soda and hot water for dipping, and it's more than enough. I've also used this recipe to make pretzel rolls - it makes 12 dinner-sized or 8 large rolls. When making rolls, I stir a couple teaspoons of soda into 1/2 cup hot water. I form the rolls, place them on a parchment-lined baking sheet, and brush them with the soda water. After they've risen until double, I brush them again, sprinkle them with kosher salt, and cut a small "x" in the top of each one. I bake them at 425 degrees for 5 minutes, then turn the oven down to 350 for 10 minutes more. They look just like store-bought pretzel rolls, but taste so much better! However I make it, this recipe is a family favorite!

text:
This is the best recipe ever (besides chocolate chip muffins)! Take my rating and multiply it by 20. If you don't know that answer, it is 100, which is what i would rate this. I halved the recipe. If you do the regular amount, take out 1 cup. If you half the recipe, take out 1/2 cup. DO NOT FORGET THE BUTTER. For every 6 pretzels, melt 2 tablespoons (1/4 stick) butter. I made 6 and made 2 salted, 2 cinnamon sugar, 2 salted and cinnamon sugar. Good every way. Remember, take out the flour, use the butter and this is a 100 STAR RECIPE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

userID:

Display Name:
heatherhickey
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First of all, to make a good pretzel, you really just need any basic dough recipe and the baking soda bath.  The baking soda bath is what makes it pretzelly.  

The key alterations I found was that I only needed about 3 cups of flour.  If you didn't read the reviews and started with 5 cups of flour, your pretzels will suck.

I also changed was only using half the amount of water/baking soda for the bath (and I still had more than I needed for 12 pretzels - you could probably 1/4 it).

4 tsp of yeast is a lot for something that doesn't actually need to ride all that much.  You can get away with just 2 or 3.

The other thing the recipe was missing was instructions for rolling out the dough.  I divided my dough into 12 parts rolled each piece between my hands into a fat snake (like you'd do with playdough).   Then I used my rolling pin to roll it into a long flat strip (about 24 inches).  Once I got the length I needed, I rounded it out to the thickness of my finger.

I also cooked mine at 450 for 15 minutes but I've seen a variety of reviews about cooking for less or lower temps.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious pretzels!!! They don't have quite the mall look, (I have a whole new appreciation for the skill it takes to shape dough into a pretzel now.) but they look, smell, and taste delicious. I read a few reviews before I tackled this recipe and the modifications were very helpful. I baked them at 400 for 10 minutes and that was perfect. (4500' elevation) A little less flour was helpful too, I think I used about 3.5 - 4.0 cups. The other modification I made was brushing on the baking soda solution vs attempting to dip the dough into it. I couldn't keep the dough from disintegrating and falling apart. (It may be because I have a highly developed skill in dunking Oreo Cookies and that technique does not transfer into dunking raw pretzel dough.) When I took them out of the oven they were golden brown and smelled wonderful. A little spray butter and whaa-laa ... delicious pretzels!!!

text:
I just made these about two hours ago, was looking for a recipe that didn't require bread flour and this fit the bill. I was able to get a crispy shell but a soft, fluffy inside. I would suggest varying the temp between 370 and 425 as some stoves may run hotter. Also, I turned the stove off when they started to get a light brown and let them set for 5 minutes. That made handling them a lot easier as well since they weren't overly hot. Other than that, this was a solid, easy to follow recipe. Thank you for sharing it, my family loved them!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was worried about this recipe while shaping the dough because it seemed to be not so smooth and too easy to rip, but my pretzels turned out beautiful. Two suggestions: First, make sure you let the baking soda solution drip well before the pretzels go in the oven, otherwise it will burn on your baking sheet (doesn't affect the pretzels, but the smell scared me enough that I took out the pretzels before they were ready). Second, if you aren't sure about whether your pretzels are done, poke them with a toothpick to see if they are doughy or chewy in the middle.

text:
I used my bread machine for this recipe to make it even easier! I changed a few quantities though; 4 cups of bread flour, I omitted the 1 tsp of sugar (as you don't need to wait for the yeast to get frothy when using the bread machine), 1 1/2 cups of warm water and used only 1 tsp of salt as the salt on the outside of the pretzel made them salty enough. They were amazing! I will definitely be using this recipe again.

text:
This is the best pretzel recipe I have tried! I have been using it for about a year now and am never disappointed. I have tried them plain, with herbs, with garlic and cheese, and with various other things in them and they are always soft and delicious. I have never been able to make them for other people unfortunately because I know I would eat them all before I made it there...
Make sure you don't add all the flour though, just add it in gradually and stop when the dough stops being sticky. I like to sprinkle kosher salt on them right after I dip them in the baking soda bath and then brush them with melted butter after they come out of the oven

None
country:
None
text:
These were amazing!  I've only recently started making bread and this was my first time attempting pretzels.  The recipe was really easy to follow.  I took the advice of a couple other reviewers and added a bit more oil & salt to the dough.  Adding the oil was a good move, I think.  I didn't have to flour the counter before turning out the dough...it was perfectly smooth and didn't stick at all.  I also used only 4 cups of flour instead of 5...for the amount of liquid, 4 just worked better.  My dough wouldn't take any more than that.  I will be making these again next weekend, both because they were a huge hit, and because I need to practice my pretzel-shaping technique  :)

Loved these! The only reason they dont get 5 stars from me is because I mad a few minor adjustments. I was unsure of how much flour to use since I read mixed reviews about the amount of flour to use. So I used 4 1/2 cups. I used my bread maker to make the dough. I did make the yeast as specified before I added the rest of the ingredients to the machine. When my dough was ready before it rose I took it out and placed it in bowl to rise and continued with the recipe as written. I had no problem rolling them out to pinky sized ropes. I also adjusted the oven temp to 415 and only made half the baking soda and water solution and it was plenty.

I made half with salt and the other half with cinnamon n sugar. For the cinnamon sugar ones I did NOT sprinkle with salt before baking. When done I dipped them in butter to help the cinnamon and sugar stick. I have 4 kids ranging in ages from 16-6 and they all loved them.

Made them as pretzel bites and the kids ate them until they were stuffed with white flour goodness.

text:
I am so excited I finally got these to work!  I have tried them many times and they always turned out like hard and dry pieces of bread. When I tried to roll the ropes they constantly crumbled and fell apart.   A few things I FINALLY did right (for those who are also struggling): 1. I added A LOT less flour - I made 1/2 batch and probably left about 2/3 cup of flour out and still had to add a few tbsp of water.  2. I timed my kneading - I think I was way under-kneading.  3. when I mixed the baking soda and water I used the hottest water I could get out of my tap AND put it in the microwave for 45 sec.  The baking soda still didn't totally dissolve but they did turn out more pretzel-brown.  I only gave 4 stars because they still aren't quite as good as the mall ones and they don't have that perfect brown crust you usually find on pretzels.  Still a great snack to make though!

text:
I loved these pretzels. I actually halved the recipe and reduced the flour to 3 cups vs. 3 1/2 cups.  I also added 2 tbs of water.  I found that this ration got the dough just right. I let the yeast, hot water and sugar proof in my bread machine and then tossed in the rest of the ingredients and set it to "dough".  Using my bread machine to knead the dough made it super easy.  A learned how to shape a pretzel by watching a YouTube video.  I was able to make 6 pretzels. I baked two and froze the shaped dough for later.  I accompanied my pretzels with marinara sauce for dipping.  I can't wait to make other flavors that you can find at the pretzel chains in the mall.

text:
These pretzels are delicious! I have made a few other pretzel recipes that I've found online, and this one is my favorite. The dough is a little difficult to knead and also difficult to roll out, but not too bad as long as you are patient. I am having a birthday party for a 3 year old in two weeks, so I have been making freeze-ahead recipes to alleviate stress the day of the party - this recipe is perfect! Of course I ate a handful of these when they came out of the oven, but the rest, I threw in a freezer Ziploc to freeze until the party! These will reheat best at 375 for 5 minutes. Also, I prefer to make a long rope out of the dough and cut into 1-inch bites rather than standard pretzels - much better for tiny little hands! Thanks for the yummy recipe!

text:
Wonderful! So light and airy! My husband even called them "heaven". I gave it four stars due to the incomplete cooking directions. I only used 4 cups of flour plus more for kneading, as recommended by another reviewer. What I should have listened to another review but didn't was only baking on the top rack. DO NOT BAKE ON BOTTOM RACK!! The bottoms will for sure burn if you do. Take your time and wait for the first batch to cook before putting more in. Also, you'll only need half of the soda mixture stated. Four cups of water and all that baking soda was WAY too much! Will definitely make again!

country:
None
text:
you defiantly need a stand mixer for this recipe. It takes more water then the recipe calls for and requires 5-7 minutes of kneading on the dough hook. best if you let them rest for about 15 min after shaping them so the dough can relax if not the dough will remain stiff and dense.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6239311.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous! My modifications include: using molasses instead of sugar to proof the yeast and half the sugar called for in the recipe for the dough. I've tried both dipping the pretzels in a hot water solution - as suggested - and in boiling water, as other recipes suggest. I prefer this method (hot water). It doesn't stop the pretzels from rising more in the oven (as the boiling method does), but I like the texture of the finished product better - slightly crispy on the outside and soft on the inside (as opposed to more chewy on the outside). They are absolutely divine fresh out the oven - but it's hard to stop at just one!

Wonderful!  Changes I made: used butter instead of oil, halved the recipe, used 1 packet of quick-rising yeast.  I found with halving the recipe and using quick-rising yeast, you need to make the ropes quite thin for them to keep the correct shape (they still taste great a little misshapen, though :)  ).

text:
I have been in love with Pretzel Maker pretzels forever. I made this recipe today and it is a dead on match! I scaled down for 6 and used only 2 cups of flour instead of 2.5 cups, and kneeded the dough for 10 min and let it rise for 2 hours. Used 1 tsp of brown sugar and 1/2 cup of brown sugar. I also baked on a cookie sheet using pam. Baked at 400 for 7=8 min and it was perfect. I dipped them in melted butter and dipped in honey mustard sauce I got from Pretzle Maker! This was my first time baking and it was so simple. Homemade pretzels it is going forward. I will never purchase Mall Pretzels ever!

text:
I used to work at Auntie Anne's, during college, and of all the recipes I've seen on the internet, this is the one that comes closest. Using a mix of bread (high gluten) and all-purpose flour makes them even better. Try topping with garlic powder and parmesan, or add jalapenos or cinnamon and raisins, to get some of the other flavors. Now if only I can figure out how to approximate the sweet almond topping...  

Making them commercially, we baked them for about for about 7 minutes at 500 degrees. I'm still playing with time and temperature to get them just right.

Display Name:
kroberts1140

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome! Buttery, flaky -- a nice pretzel. My husband enjoys that light hint of sweetness. It does remind me of a mall pretzel. I made some small modifications. On initial mixing of the dry ingredients, I started with about a half cup less flour, made my well, incorporated the yeast mix and oil into the dry, but added more flour as I went to achieve the exact consistency I was looking for -- smooth but not overly wet. My yeast was a little old, so I let it rise longer. I divided into slightly larger balls to make eleven, that way I could make longer ropes, and the little "faces" in the knots stretched and set nice from baking soda bath to pan. I lightly greased 2 of my glass 9 by 13 inch pans with unsalted butter and used coarse sea salt for my topping. I baked in the top tier of my oven and basted with salted butter halfway through baking and again to finish. I needed to increase my bake time slightly, and I did them in two batches. I basted again when they finished. Next time, I will experiment with different flavor toppings -- cinnamon, maybe garlic powder, the possibilities are endless :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very yummy! We halved the recipe but made no other changes as far as ingredients. 

When it came to the baking soda bath, I followed a review from another recipe here and actually boiled the pretzels in the bath for about 15 seconds. I found that the longer they boiled, the darker the crust gets when baked (I miss timed the first one or two!). This also made them tougher. So if you prefer softer, stick with 15-20 seconds.

We then brushed with butter and sprinkled with the kosher salt. Baked at a lower temp, 425 degrees, for 8 minutes (per another review). 

They cam out wonderfully! Will definitely make these again for snacks sometime!

April Huntley

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just took these out of the oven, and the looks and turned out great! I followed the recipe exactly, (which I never do, but this is my first attempt at pretzels) and I will admit, I had m doubts. First of all, the dough was the toughest dough I have ever had to knead, and I was scared it wouldn't rise...but being my optimistic self (haha) I set it aside to let it do it's thing, and an hour later, I was pleasantly shocked to see that the dough had risen awesomely. So then I turned it out to my *ahem*lightly floured surface, sprinkled a bit of flour on top, and gave it a couple of kneads, cut it into the 12 pieces and began to roll it out....however, I must have used too much flour, and it was dry..dry..dry. I was devastated....till I figured I would just sprinkle a couple drops of water on the dough...and sure enough, though it felt wet, it rolled out beautifully! This dough is very forgiving!!!!  As a side note..it would be very easy to stuff as well, and I think I may try it next time..with cheese, or chocolate...or pizza stuffed...or ham and cheese stuffed...the possibilities are endless! I just shaped 1/12 of the dough out like I was going to make the pretzel, and then used the rolling pin to flatten it out...you could stuff it, close it up, and bake it accordingly....could be good! Thanks for the recipe!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe!  I followed the directions except I omitted all sugar (except for the sugar that is mixed with the yeast).  If you don't want sweet pretzels, this is the way to do it.  Also, 2 minutes before they were done baking, I brushed melted butter on them and put them back in the oven.  
A few things about making these...  Roll them out really long (almost 1 1/2 feet) and roll them out in your hands starting at one end (with dough hanging) and working your way to the other end.  It's almost impossible to roll them out on a surface.  Also, I think that the dough needed about 1/4 cup more water (or more).  Lastly, they need a bit longer than 8 minutes to cook in order to get browned nicely.
Next time, I will try substituting some whole wheat flour for the all-purpose flour and maybe brush the pretzels with egg whites before cooking, because the baking soda didn't make the surface crackle (I assume that was the desired effect).  It didn't effect the taste either though--they were great!

text:
I had been craving soft pretzels and after having success making bread using yeast, I had a lot of confidence so decided to go for this recipe.  I ended up using 4 cups of flour and added 3 TSP of water because the dough was dry, but figured it will all work out.  Instead of vegetable oil, I used coconut oil and used coconut oil to grease the pan.  I ended up putting too much of it and it was everywhere...all over the dough, too.  I made pretzel sticks since that was easier and my dough wasn't really staying put with so much oil on it.  I baked at 400 degrees and 8 minutes was too short.  I probably baked 5 minutes longer and then dipped it in butter and added a little sea salt and it tasted really delicious.

text:
These are absolutely some of the best pretzels I have ever had. I made the recipe as stated adding as much flour as I needed to get a good soft dough. The baking soda bath gives them that great bitter pretzel flavor and a chewy texture to the crust. After baking, I dipped each in melted butter and sprinkled with coarse salt. They're also great dipped in butter and sprinkled with cinnamon and sugar. Next time I will probably make some of each and a sweet cream cheese dipping sauce for the sweet pretzels. I made these for a party and they were a HUGE hit.

text:
These really tasted amazing.  We live 45 minutes from a pretzel place, I'm pregnant and on a baking spree--I can see these becoming a "gotta have."  
I used only 4 cups of flour and a much cooler oven (slightly over 400) for a few extra minutes. I also only had regular table salt so I used that and with melted butter it was spectacular (though I usually wipe the coarse salt off of my soft pretzels).
I did have trouble getting the dough to roll thin enough, but I think next time I'll just make a few long, thick "snakes" and try making big pretzel sticks.  I'm thinking Superbowl party. Oh yum.

text:
I've never left a review here before but this was one I just had to.  I just finished making these and they are half gone - SO YUMMY!!  I love mall pretzels and these are just as good if not better.  Followed some suggestions and used 3.5 cups of flour and added another 1/2 cup when I was kneading it.  Also I put the oven at 400 and the rack on the top.  I also used 2 packets of active dry yeast which was not exactly 4 tsp but it worked just fine.  Turned out perfect.  I salted most but left some plain.  When they came out I brushed all with melted butter and added more salt to the salty ones and cinnamon and sugar to the others - SO GOOD!!

I was looking for an Aunt Annie's copy cat type recipe and this one caught my eye. Follow directions exactly but used 4 1/2 cups of flour instead of 5 as some reviewers suggested.   If you want the pretzels to be large like Aunt Annie's - cut dough into 6 equal portions to make ropes.  With 12 divisions the pretzels were about 6" pretzels.  Family raved about them.  Going to try freezing and see how they thaw/microwave for quick snacks. thanks for the recipe - Yum....

This recipe went pretty well for me: it was the VERY FIRST time I ever used yeast and I really had no clue what I was doing. Because I was not baking for many people, and because of my lack of confidence in yeast-baking skills, I halved the recipe. It worked out just fine! It is satisfying to have a recipe go well, so thank you so much!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A great, fun and easy recipe. Thought I would give it a try as pretzel rolls are hard to find in bakeries here. This was so easy and tasty that we actually made them 2 days in a row, trying a few different additions and substitutions. I used a dough hook on my stand mixer and let it knead the dough. That worked wonderfully, however I found I needed quite a bit extra water added to get the right bread dough consistency. Instead of adding oil, I melted a tablespoon of unsalted butter. It added a nice, subtle buttery flavor to the finished pretzel. As I was looking for pretzel rolls, I followed this recipe and then shaped the dough into sticks and they came out perfectly, only having to adjust the baking time. The baking time for sticks was nearly double, but worth it. My next try is going to be with rye flour and carroway seeds. Then I might try wrapping the dough around a hot dog before the bath and bake, making pretzel dogs! Whatever the outcome, this is the best recipe I've found. We've got our pretzel rolls for Oktoberfest!

text:
I followed the recipe pretty much to the tee, and these turned out AMAZING! I only used 1/4 cup of baking soda in 3 cups of warm water as that was all I had and they browned beautifully. When they came out of the oven I dunked them in melted butter and then coated them in a cinnamon/sugar mixture. I used about 2 cups of white sugar and 1/4 cup of cinnamon and found that to be an excellent balance! Tasted even better then mall pretzels! I will make these again and again!

text:
These are fantastic!! and a must try!  The recipe is perfect and didn't change a thing. With that said, I did follow the comment from another review that suggested after dipping the pretzel in the hot water/baking soda bath to place the pretzel on paper towel to take off the excess water.  Also I did lower my oven temp. to 400F.  At 400F, 8mins in the oven was sufficient.  I found these 2 minor changes helpful, and my pretzel's slide right off the baking sheet.  Will be making these again, and again!!

text:
I would give these 4 stars because they were really tasty, but nothing like pretzels I've bought. The sough was WAY too sweet for pretzel dough. Next time I will use half the sugar. Also, the dough was really stiff, and took almost 2 hours to raise, and that was in an 86º room. Then, as I rolled them out and shaped them, the dough kept springing back so I had to rest it twice before final shaping. As they baked, they rose so much my family commented they no longer looked like pretzels but more like a knotted roll. Just not what I expected from a "pretzel" recipe, though I will use it for rolls.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/91857.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! I did decrease the flour to 4 cups per other reviewers. I have been making my own bread for years, and the second time I made these I made a mistake with the yeast/sugar/water mixture. I usually will put the water and sugar in the bowl first and then add the yeast. For some reason, that time I put the yeast/sugar in the bowl first and then added the water. When I went to put the wet mixture into the dry after the ten minutes, there was undissolved yeast in the bottom of the bowl. So, always make sure you add the yeast LAST! It didn't seem to make a difference in this recipe, but it may in other bread recipes. Thanks for sharing- the pretzels are a huge hit in my house!

Fantastic recipe. I reduced the flour by 1/2 a cup.  I divided the dough into 8 balls and rolled them out into six pretzels.  The remaining two balls I seperated and rolled out into ropes for pretzels, dunked in the bath, and the wrapped them around precooked hot dogs.  They were amazing! text:
These were a HUGE hit! My kids had a blast helping me make them. The key is to definitely roll them out super skinny (like your pinky width) It looks too skinny, but they puff up when they bake. I reduced baking temp to 415 degrees, and that seemed perfect.  I have found that the amount of flour you need, depends on where you live and what kind of flour you are using. I had to use more than what the recipe called for to have the dough not be sticky. So, start with 4 cups and then adjust from there.  I only wish they browned better. I will try an egg wash as another user sugg. next time.  Can't wait to make them again.

text:
These DO taste like the mall pretzels!  I followed another reviewer's advice and ignored mixing the dry and wet ingredients separately. I first mixed the wet (plus salt and sugar) with the yeast, then after it "proofed" added as much flour as necessary. It was almost 5 cups. Also, you don't need 4 cups water and 1/2 a cup baking soda for the bath!! WAY too much, you can easily halve that and have lots left over.  Other than that, perfect, easy, and tasty. My husband told me that he didn't really like pretzels, but I had him eat a bite and his reaction was basically he was blown away, melting practically. He just ate another one! I might have to hide a few for myself. Thanks for the recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have a pretzel recipe I usually use, but decided to try this one.  I changed the recipe a little based on other reviews and what I had on hand:    I swapped out 1 cup of flour for whole wheat flour, and didn't use the whole 5 cups - more likely 4-ish (just enough so dough wasn't sticky).  I used only one packet yeast (2 1/4 tsp) and substituted a melted butter/margarine blend for the vegetable oil.  These have good flavor and are soft/tender.  My other recipe turns out chewier with a harder crust, which I tend to prefer, but these are great if you like a really soft pretzel!  Also, I've found that if you're not concerned about having these look like pretzels, it's easier to divide the dough into 24 pieces and make pretzel 'sticks'.     Either way, make sure to stick parchment or waxed paper on top of your baking sheet - the baking soda wash baked onto metal is a pain to get off.

userID:
1421576
Display Name:
ATLMICHELLE
isPro:
False
followersCount:
12

125
favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/285998.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have one word to describe these pretzels: HEAVEN.  These were a huge hit at my Oktoberfest party and I am definitely keeping this recipe forever. They were not difficult to make at all and I had no problems getting them rolled into long ropes and shaped into pretzels.  My tips are:  (1) I found that dipping them in the water/soda solution when they were a long rope was much easier than forming them first and then dipping them.  (2) Definitely blot on a paper towel briefly after dipping them in the water so the water solution doesn't puddle on the baking sheet. (3) You can easily make them the night before you need them. Just skip putting salt on them, bake them off, cool and store them in an airtight container. When you are ready to serve, take a basting brush and brush a small amount of water on them, sprinkle with salt and bake at 300 degrees for 10 minutes.  They were perfectly crispy and tasted like I had just made them. Divine!!

text:
i'm updating my review (which i posted yesterday). i was able to finally get the consistency and texture of the dough correct (2nd try). but i used 2 cups wheat flour and 2 cups white flour as well as replacing white sugar with brown sugar (this combo was suggest by other users). bad mistake. don't mess with the recipe! don't know how the brown sugar affects taste, but adding the wheat flour was a problem. my pretzels made with all white flour and white sugar tasted like they came from the mall. the ones with wheat flour taste like a wheat dinner bun. i love wheat bread and all, but this is supposed to be a pretzel. so stick with the recipe (using only 4 cups of flour, not 5). good luck!

text:
My first try at making pretzels. Success! This recipe is terrific. I used only 4-1/2 cups of flour. It made very pliable dough which was easy to roll out on a clean, unfloured surface. I didn't roll my dough pieces long and thin enough before shaping the pretzels so they came out chubby-my bad!  After their soda bath half of them got salted and half got cinnamon sugar. They had plenty of buttery delicious flavor without further addition of butter. I'll make again and again!

text:
These were awesome. However, I decreased the flour to 4 cups and still used about an extra 1/4 cup of water. If you make this into 12 pretzels, they come out tiny. If you want the same size pretzels that you buy at the mall you really only get 5 or 6 out of this recipe. I also subbed melted smart balance buttery spread with olive oil for all the oil in the recipe to save a few calories. I decreased the temp to 425 and increased the time to 10 minutes. These aren't just like Auntie Annie's pretzels at the mall but they are close and really good.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am a sucker for the pretzels at the mall and always have to get one when I am there.  I have moved out to the country and don't get out as often as I used to.  When I saw this recipe on the home page I had to try it.  I  cut the recipe in half and made the dough in my breadmaker.  I would have had plenty of room for a full recipe but I am the only one in the house who eats soft pretzels.  When the dough cycle finished I rolled out the dough to approximately 3/4 - 1 inch thickness and cut it into strips to make pretzel sticks.  I dipped them in solution and let them drip dry on a rack before salting them lightly and baking them for 7 minutes.  When they got out of the oven I brushed a tablespoon of melted butter over the tops of the sticks.  These were just as good if not better than mall pretzels!  This recipe is a keeper!  I can't wait until my little girl gets older and I can make her all these great goodies I am finding on allrecipes.com!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love, love, LOVE this recipe! I've made it twice. The first time was a practice run, it took a while to perfect the pretzel shape. Second time they were BEAUTIFUL! I made four different flavors...plain, cinnamon, ranch, and Parmesan & garlic. Instead of rolling the dough into ropes, I left it flat after rolling it out. I then brushed butter on the surface and topped with cinnamon, powdered ranch dip mix, or powdered garlic and dry Parmesan cheese. I twisted the dough with the flavor on the inside and then shaped into pretzels. It's a good idea to use separate bowls to dip the dough in because some of the flavor will end up in the water...cinnamon and garlic might not taste that great. ;) I will definitely make these again, and already have requests piling up.

text:
These pretzels are a crowd favorite among my group of friends. Whenever we have gatherings, I am responsible for bringing the pretzels. Even my friends who are professional chefs love this recipe! They match or beat any pretzel that you would find in the mid-Atlantic region. They are very easy and fun to make! I use the baking soda mixture and sprinkle kosher salt on them before baking. I don't worry about them getting stale - they are gone before that could happen. The only downfall is that fresh bread goes bad quickly in the south because of the humidity....to no fault of the pretzel!

text:
This recipe was so easy and amazingly good.  I cut the recipe in half as a test batch and used kosher salt in the recipe. I used coarse sea salt on top. My oven runs hot so I watched them carefully during baking time so they would not burn.  I used parchment paper to line the baking sheets and I recommend using parchment paper in all bread baking projects because it does prevent burning and sticking on the bottoms.  I will definitely make these again and try various toppings and shapes just for the fun of it. 4 and a half stars!

text:
I thought these were really good. I've made them twice so far, in 4 days and well, here is my suggestions.    Do not add all the flour. I did that the first time and came out with tough dough. I only added 4 cups and only needed a little more while kneading it. I also did not need any while rolling out the ropes. I made small pretzels and came out with about 20 or so. I let the dough rise for more than an hour and it was perfect dough. They are best if used the same day. This sure is a keeper! Thanks.

text:
These ended up really great, but I wish I'd read reviews before I started them. I prepared them exactly as the recipe states, but next time I'm adding the flour in last and not all at once, because it was definintely too much flour, and it wasn't very smooth at all. I think adding the flour at the end would make it more smooth. But it did end up working out, just really hard to knead, and took a lot longer to rise as well. Tasted great though, and when my husband and I finished them all, I wished I had made the whole batch and not just half a batch. Oh, we did boil the water before dunking the pretzels in, everything I've heard about pretzels before says that's the way to do it. I also used olive oil rather than veggie oil, presonal prefrence. Anyway, thanks for the recipe, though I am going to tweak it next time I make it.

text:
These completely fixed my mall-pretzel craving.  They tasted exactly the same.  The only things I changed in the recipe were to add the flour last so that I could get the right consistency for the dough, and to use a little less sugar in the dough.  I ended up using 4 1/2 cups flour and 1/3 cup sugar for the dough. I skipped adding the coarse salt on a few pretzels, then when they were done I brushed them with butter and sprinkled with cinnamon and sugar for the kids.  They were a huge hit.

These are very good.  To speed up the doubling time, I sat the dough on the counter over the dishwasher when i ran a load through.  The extra heat worked like a charm.  I also patted the dough out into a huge rectangle so that I could cut the 12 pieces into long strips.  This made rolling them very easy and made all uniform in size.

I followed the recipe exatly and I had trouble, it was VERY dry and I ended up adding about 5 T. water. Also they were easier to roll out on a NON floured surface. And the baking time needs to be longer at a slightly lower temp. Like 12-15 min at 400...or else the insides will be soggy/doughy and you'll have to bake longer anyway. The end result was NOT anything like the Mall Pretzels. I was disappointed. I'll have to try another pretzel recipe another day.

text:
So good!! These taste just like Auntie Anne's pretzels!  I used 4 cups of all-purpose flour and a little extra water for moisture.  Right when they come out of the oven I dip them in butter and sprinkle again with kosher salt.  This recipe is a keeper!
Just a little tip: sometimes when I have trouble getting the dough to rise I heat the oven for a minute or two just until warm and then turn it off and put the bowl with covered dough in and leave the door closed.  Works everytime.

Yum!  These are so good!  I opted not to add the salt to the top. Display Name:
Tulips*n*Truffles
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/106587.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just pulled my first batch out of the oven! YUMM-O! There were a couple of things I wish I'd have paid more attention to. First, my dough didn't double...not even close. I'm sure I either have old yeast or I killed it with water that was too hot...but I went ahead and used it anyway. Second, while I *meant* to cut the dough into 12, I blanked for a bit and cut it into 8 instead. No biggie. The baking soda/water worked great. Into the oven. I baked at 400 for 10 minutes and I'm glad I did! The bottoms are over-brown and the tops got brown really really fast. I wish I could have left them in the oven another minute or two, but the bottoms would have been black! The flavor, however, is SO GOOD! Really dense (that's why I wish I could have baked them longer). Next time, I may lower the oven temperature even further, and bake them on parchment. I'm pretty sure that soda/water reacts with the metal and that doesn't help the bottoms one bit! BUT I'd make these again in a heartbeat! The flavor is great, they look great, and they're such a great snack! Thanks for the recipe!!

text:
This will be the only bread recipe I will use. I have tried it with all purpose flour, whole wheat and now with pastry flour. I really liked the pastry flour batch as the crumb was finer. I have also experimented with adding a bit more oil to keep them from drying out the next day. It also works well.The soda mixture is a must. I have brushed some with butter/cinnamon/brown sugar and the other half i rolled them in some coco powder. Everyones gotta try this recipe at least once!!

text:
This recipe was great!!  I used my bread machine dough cycle.  I did add a little more water (2-3 T) as it was kneeding because my machine seemed to be bogging down.  After the cycle just turned them on a floured board and cut into 12 pieces and rolled out, dipped in the soda water and baked.  They were great the next morning too.  Just put them in the oven on 350 for 10 min.  Dipped in honey mustard.  

This recipe is defiantly a keeper!!!

text:
It was by far one of the greatest recipes for soft pretzels I have ever made. the result was heavy, and very satisfying pretzels, even my drywall guy agreed they were great.
Improvements could be made in the Baking soda mixture. It was good, but I figured less baking soda, and add alot of salt so it was salted on the outside too, and then immediately after it comes out of the oven, it was absolutely delicous to lightly "paint" it with melted butter using a brush.

I HIGHLY SUGGEST YOU MAKE THESE TERRIFIC PRETZELS

Display Name:
Winter Ivy

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/83385.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This a recipe I am definately keeping on file.  I love sweet and salty, and this is yet another great recipe to indulge that craving!  I served them with cheese sauce at a family game of Texas Hold 'Em and all 12 were GONE in an hour.  They were very easy.  The only change I made, due to the urging of other reviewers, was that I cut the flour down to 4.5 cups.  I did the dough in the bread machine which made it even easier.  I did the water/yeast/sugar step first right in the bread machine pan, then added the rest of the wet ingredients, then the dry.  When the dough cycle was done, it was perfect...non-sticky dough that I barely had to flour my surface at all to work with.  I was skeptical of the baking soda dip, because I have always seen them done with an egg wash...but it was so good, made the outsides nice and brown and "cracked" like real pretzels.  Sprinkled on some sea salt and baked them on a parchment lined pan and they were perfect!  Soft, chewy, and a little bit sweet...YUM!

text:
These were VERY good and I highly recommend them. But, I am giving them 4/5 stars because 5 cups is way too much flour-- if you use that you will keep having to add water to the dough because its too dry. I tried the recipe as-is, but I would say to definitely follow the  recommendations to use only 4 cups. Also, for me, 8 mins. baking was about 1 minute too long, because the bottoms burned a little. I did a few with regular salt, and a few brushed with butter and a cinnamon/sugar mixture. Thanks for the recipe, with those small changes, its a 10 star recipe!!!

I read the other reviews first so I knew to add a little less flour.I also followed the advice to lower the oven temp a bit because my oven runs hot. I baked them at 400.
 The dough came out just fine, not dry and tasted very good. It did puff up a little more than I would expect for pretzels but I kinda eye balled the yeast so perhaps I put in a touch too much. The flavor was nice and the dough was the perfect soft type pretzel consistency and texture. I also made great bread sticks with it!

text:
I'm giving this recipe a four b/c if I had not cut the salt by over 1/2 as rec. by other reviewers, it would have been too salty.  Also, keep an eye on them while cooking so the top/bottom doesn't burn.  I took mine out a couple minutes early and they were perfect.  But with the variations, the prezels were very good. My husband who said he 'wasn't a pretzel guy' ended up eating two!  We dipped them in a cream cheese/cinnamon/sugar mixture.  Yum!  One other hint: If you have a mixer, use it with the dough attachment instead of doing it by hand. Saves a lot of time!

text:
These were very good - and quicker than most things with yeast since they didn't have to rise twice.  The dough was a bit more dense than I expected, but good once cooked.  We did cinnamon & sugar, glaze, cheese sauce, and caramelized onions (baked in).

text:
these were okay... if we make them again they'll need some changes though. i should have read the reviews first. i definitely should have added more water and less salt. we added about 4 tbsp water to the dough to get it to ball up, but then after letting it rise and trying to shape the pretzels, it was incredibly tough and hard to work with. we didn't have as much fun trying to shape them as we have with prior recipes. this was more like a chore. i also found that they were too thick for the baking time, but starting getting very brown very quickly, so i had to cover them with foil for the last several minutes of baking. they do have a nice, chewy texture and i like the sweetness, but i wish they would have rolled out thinner and that they were less salty-- and we didn't even add kosher to the top.

These pretzels came out looking fantastic and tasted wonderful.  I did find that I needed to add quite a bit of additional water to make the dough.  I had no idea if they would turn out or not, because the dough was so dry.  I also made mine a little thicker so had to increase the baking time.  I'll make again!
Update: I made this recipe again with 4 cups of flour and it was perfect.  I also shaped these into rolls and used them for turkey sandwiches.  Yum.

userID:
1470786
Display Name:
Jbowser

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I felt that this recipe was laid out well, that the time estimate was right on track. I made the dough in the food processor, so did not knead the dough. I processed it until it made a ball, had to add a quarter to a half cup of warm water to get it to ball up, but then it balled up nicely. I then pulsed it for 50 seconds in all to knead it.

I did not have trouble making ropes, but needed a countertop with no flour on it to roll them out. 

The oven temp baked them to perfection at the given time. They were beautiful, if a little bland tasting. I was conservative with the salt, having read reviews that stated the pretzels were too salty. I didn't find them salty enough!

Next time I will be experimenting a little with some additional flavoring in the dough. 

All in all a great dough recipe. I love a dough that rises well and is easy to work with.

This one goes in the keeper file for sure!

text:
I didn't read the reviews until in the middle of making when the dough was so dry I was going "What did I do wrong?!"  Added quite a bit more water to make it more manageable and it was not a fun task of kneading and rolling out the dough.  The end result was wonderful, though!  Tasted a lot like mall pretzels, and I liked the sweetness so wouldn't change that... I will probably not make these again- too much work when I live right by an Auntie M's, but they were delicious fresh, especially dipped in cheese sauce.

text:
I must say that I really enjoyed the pretzels, My kids have food allergies and these were great being that they had no dairy products in them. I however found that I needed more water in the mixture and needed to let the dough rise for about 3 hours, I was skeptical at first being that after just 1 hour of letting the dough rise it was really stringy, so I let ir rest for a little bit longer and they turned out great.

text:
This is a great recipe--much better than anything available in the mall. I substituted butter for the oil and bread flour for all-purpose flour. Bread flour probably made the dough a bit more difficult to roll out, but the final product rose and browned nicely in the oven. 

These were a little sweet for my taste. Next time, I'll try about 1/3 cup instead.

text:
These are quite good, although I wouldn't say they're quite like mall pretzels.  I kept trying to roll the dough into a thin rope but it kept bouncing back and I inevitably had plump, thick pretzels (this didn't detract from the taste, it was just frustrating that they woulnd't hold their shape a little better).  My kids LOVE these with Campbell's condensed cheddar cheese sauce (heated up with just a little bit of milk, NOT a whole can).  Also it's nice not to have to boil them in the baking soda bath, just a quick dip and onto the cookie sheet.  We'll make these lots.

Display Name:
artisanrox

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2615784.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I read a bunch of comments beforehand so I did as suggested and reduced the sugar to just three or four tablespoons.  Used butter instead of oil.  I pretty much made this like a loaf of bread...put all the wet ingredients in the stand mixer and added enough flour to that to make the dough (I didn't do the "well" thing).  Making sure your baking soda is fresh, lining your sheets with parchment paper, drying the pretzels in a towel, and putting the sheet way at the top of the oven are all really important!  Instead of making a dozen it was easier to keep splitting the dough in half so I ended up with 16 larger pretzels (after doubling this recipe).  I brushed melted butter on them when out of the oven.  I gave half to a neighbor  (sad but had to be done) and we ate the vast majority of them right out of the oven!  Will make many times over now!!

text:
This recipe was really good and really forgiving. I kneaded it almost too much and it still came out really soft and fluffy. The amount of flour was fine and I only had to add maybe a 1/4 C water when kneading it.  The people who said it was too much either didn't measure out the flour right (ie. scooped instead of pouring the flour into the measuring cup) or didn't knead it enough to incorporate all of it. I topped some of it with Trader Joe's Everything bagel seasoning and it was amazing.

text:
A basic pretzel recipe that gets a few things wrong. The quantity of flour is a large overestimate. I had to add ½-1½ cups of water before the dough was hydrated enough. 

Also, there is no need for sugar, especially not this much in a pretzel recipe. It makes it taste weirdly sweet when you make savoury pretzels. So after tasting the first test pretzel, I decided to make the rest into doughnuts.

text:
Fantastic!  Made exactly as written.  Served with creamy horseradish dip and mustard for dipping.  I made these for a football game party and they were gone in minutes.

For the flour comments, I weighed my flour instead of measuring.  I do this because flour can become compacted in the cup and you may get more than needed.  Also, as soon as they come out of the oven, I brushed with warm butter.

I am from Philadelphia and went to school in Lancaster, Pa.  this is the best recipe EVER.  I did add some honey to the bowl with butter and allowed the dough to rise in this bowl for 4 hours...I had a doctor's appointment and had to leave it in the oven to rise.  It made 300 pretzel bites which I sell at my deli with beer cheese soup.  I typically bake the bites and then store them away and then quickly fry them in deep oil prior to arranging them on the plate with the bowl of soup in the middle.  Who ever created this recipe....I love you!

None
text:
AMAZING and easier than I thought it would be. A few changes I made:
I doubled the baking soda water mixture and boiled each pretzel in the water individually for about 30 seconds each. 
I used 4 cups of flour and even then added about 1/4 cup of extra water. 
I lined my pans with aluminum foil and oiled them they still stuck a little but it was easier to pull away. 
I baked them at 425 instead of 450 on the middle rack so that the bottoms wouldn’t burn. 
I used pink salt on top instead of kosher 
I buttered them all right when they came out of the oven with a brush

text:
I used the heavy duty KitchenAid mixer to mix the dough (used a dough hook).  Added a tad more water.  Used a hand mixer to mix the hot water and baking soda (I put water in microwave for 90 seconds for each of the 4 cups).  I baked for 3 1/2 minutes and then flipped over for another 3 1/2 minutes to eliminate a burned bottom.  Put the kosher salt in a shaker for more even salting.  I will try using butter rather than oil next time.  Thanks for the recipe!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are really good.  I ended up using 4 1/2 cups of flour.  I added the extra tsp of oil like suggested.  I started with 3 cups of flour in my kitchen aid with the dough hook on slow speed.  I kept adding flour a little at a time until the dough was no longer sticky.  I formed them like another reviewer suggested.  Cut a rectangular piece from the dough ball with a pizza cutter.  Start in the middle and rub back and forth between your hands holding it up in the air not on the counter.  Then I rubbed one end at  a time until it was 18-20 inches long and about as big around as my little finger.  I made them a little smaller and baked for 7 1/2 minutes.   I made beer cheese dip to go with them  YUM

Display Name:
MomCarole

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe exactly and was so disappointed with the results.  The recipe calls for way too much flour.  If I were to make them again, I would cut the amount down to 4 cups to begin with.  Being that there was too much flour, I had to add almost a 1/2 cup of additional water.  I also kneaded the dough for the recommended time.  I had a terrible time trying to get the dough to stretch.  After baking them, I ended up with pretzel "blobs".  They tasted ok, but the dough was awful to work with.  After checking out other recipes, most of them recommend a shorter kneading time in order to not toughen the dough thus making it unmanageable.   Also, the author of the recipe should have told you to heavily grease the cookie sheets because the pretzels will stick.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
Lots wrong with this recipe.  The liquid to dry ingredients ratio was WAY off. I kept back a cup of flour after reading someone's review thinking it couldn't be THAT wrong. But even that wasn't enough to leave out of it. Recipe calls for probably twice as much flour as needed.  And the baking soda dip before baking - maybe too much soda in it? Anyhow,  my pretzels have a strong flavour of soda. They were edible with my modifications, but as written this would never have worked. I sprinkled ours with cinnamon and sugar after brushing with melted butter.

text:
This was my first time making pretzels. I formed some into sticks, some into nuggets, and some into actual pretzels. I basted some garlic butter on all of them after they came out of the oven. Next time, I will use less flour, 5 cups was too much! I kept adding water, but since I'm so used to baking sweets, I didn't want to stray too far... now I know to start with less flour and add more as needed. The pretzel-shapes ones were too bready for me, the garlic butter added much needed flavor and texture! I do recommend trying sticks (reduce baking time if you opt for "nuggets")!

text:
What a bad recipe. There is way too much flour called for and every other positive review mentions this fact. If every single review mentions that there is too much flour, then it's not a good recipe. I made the mistake of not reading the reviews and just trusting the stars and the fact that allrecipes made it into a video. I made it and noticed that there was too much flour. I added an extra 1/2 cup of water in the hopes of fixing it. It didn't. Don't use this recipe without severely cutting down on the amount of flour.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making pretzels.  I, too, found it helpful to watch the video of Auntie Anne's pretzel making.  I didn't have to flour the board at all.  But, this is a very springy/elastic dough that needed to be stretched.  Even though I rolled each piece out to about 24", they still shortened up to make chubby pretzels...but they were delicious!  I made 1/2 of the recipe for just the 2 of us this time, and it yielded 6 medium sized pretzels.  I used parchment paper sprayed with non-stick spray and blotted the pretzels on paper towels before placing them on the parchment paper. No sticking or burned bottoms. I also reduced the oven temp. to 415-degrees to avoid the burning/uneven baking problems others reported.  I made a dip for the pretzels called, "Slow Cooker Cheddar Bacon Beer Dip" from the Taste of Home website which proved to be a nice combination.  I plan to make these again sometime and experiment with some different toppings to change up the flavors.  It was a fun baking activity for a laid back Saturday afternoon.

country:
None
text:
I’ve always thought making pretzels would be way harder, but this recipe was easy to follow and tasted good on my first try. 
One hurdle I encountered, however, was not letting the bottoms of my pretzels burn. Maybe the baking trays I used were too thin, but I’ve come up with a solution. I placed a pizza mesh on top of the tray, so the mesh was suspended over the tray. I then put parchment paper on top of the mesh. When baking the pretzels like this, the bottoms didn’t burn.

These are really good. I substituted the oil for butter and had to add a bit more water to the batter as it was super dry. I didn’t use the full 1/4 cup flaky sea salt, I just sprinkle it according to my liking. Baked at 190C fan on pan lined with parchment paper for about 10 minutes! Once it came out of the oven, I brushed melted salted butter on each pretzel. Will be using this recipe again.

text:
As many of you suggested, I used less sugar and only 4 cups of flour and these turned out wonderfully! They're fluffy, buttery, and form a nice brown crust on the outside while remaining soft on the inside. I used half the dough for regular pretzels and used the other half to make pretzel dogs. I brushed them with melted butter once they came out of the oven and they were delicious. Can't wait to try these again with cinnamon sugar. With some slight alterations, this recipe is fantastic. I have almost no experience with breadmaking so if I could do it, anyone can do it! Thanks so much for sharing!

country:

text:
I have to say that I do like the taste of the pretzels; however, I may have made a few mistakes. First, I probably could have waited awhile longer for the dough to rise because it didn't look like it had doubled. Second, the dough was just not pliable enough for me to roll it out easily. My hands and lower arms are still a feeling the pressure and I baked them two days ago. The baking soda bath didn't exactly do that good of a job getting them to brown, but I think it could have been because I was dipping the pretzels in as I was doing them and that took about an hour or so to finish. Another thing I did wrong was that I had left the bottom shelf on the bottom slot so the pretzels on the bottom rack got charred on the bottom. I'm going to try this again next month and I'm going to try tweaking the recipe a bit to see if I do better. I don't want to put my hands and arms through so much torture.

helpfulCount:

userID:
3837620
Display Name:
darkyetlovely
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
29
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5349172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I read many reviews before deciding to try the recipe as is and go from there. As I always do when making bread recipes, I made sure the water was 110ºf before adding the yeast and sugar in. I used the 5 cups of flour and just added 2 TBSP of warm water to make it PERFECT. I also read someone recommend adding an additional tsp of oil instead of flouring the counter surface. And this was a super great tip as well. I used the dough hook on my KitchenAid and let it knead for 7 minutes. I cut each piece into a 4oz size, used a jump rope motion 2-3 times (per someone else's suggestion; 4-5 was too much I learned once.) I folded each piece and then rolled it to about half of the size it would end up and set this aside to work on the next one. I came back and rolled it out to 30". Put it in a U shape, twisted the ends together 2x and brought down to the bottom of the U to make a beautiful pretzel shape. I soaked 4 at a time in the baking soda water for 30ish seconds. I baked 4 at a time (per someone's review/ suggestion) on parchment paper with a little cooking spray. First 4 were 8 minutes at 450º, it was a little dark but not burnt like others had suggested but I decided to turn it down to 415º like some had suggested. The second bake was it going from 450 to 415 and was a lighter brown. The third bake was at 415º and this one was lighter. They all looked pretty. Taste-wise, we liked the one baked at 450º the most. 10/10 would recommend!
Review:

text:
These are perfectly good pretzels. My family loved them, and they are soft. However, this recipe is not for those that are fond of a good crust on their pretzels. It is important to not over-knead this dough because if you develop the gluten too well, it is significantly harder to roll out.

text:
Made this almost exactly as written except I halved the recipe, added an extra teaspoon of oil and used half the amount of baking soda in the wash.   They were delicious and my Mom said they were better than Auntie Anne's.  The only problem I had was that the dough shrank back as I tried to roll it out and I couldn't get super long thin ropes, so instead of twisted pretzels I just made long pretzel "sticks" but no one minded, they were really good.  Brushed them with melted butter and sprinkled kosher salt on top right when they came out of the oven and we were all really happy with them.  Recipe is a keeper, but I'll have to do some research as to why the dough would shrink back like that.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5043915.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tastes great.  I think some of the people saying the recipe calls for too much flour may accidentally be 'over-measuring'.  I'm always surprised by how many people don't know this, but there are methods for measuring flour.  For this recipe I 'fluffed' the flour first.  Took a spoon and fluffed the flour in the container to 'break it up' and make it look 'fluffy'.  Then spoon the flour into a measuring cup until you have a mound and then take the handle of the spoon (or use a knife) and level/scrap-off the excess back into the container.

Doing this, the 5 cups of flour in the recipe wasn't too much.  That said, I followed another reviewer's advice and started with 3.5 cups flour and kneaded in the remaining flour.  I also used Olive Oil instead of Vegetable Oil.
Review:

text:
This was a really great recipe. I did have to add more liquid the next few times I made it. It seems to work much better it you add it to the beginning yeast mixture. I have made it several times already. The only difference I make is... I dip the pretzels in simmering water and baking soda until the pretzels rise to the top of the water. They seem to be more light and fluffy on the inside that way. My family and I really like it. I also like to put a light egg wash on the top. I find they cook more evenly and have less darker brown spots. I am totally a Soft Pretzel fan.
