I followed others' instructions and started with 3 cups of flour and an extra tablespoon of oil. I added the last 2 cups of flour in 1/2 cup increments, but ended up using all of it. I ended up cutting the dough into 24 small pieces for smaller portions and more to share! I decreased the baking soda in the water to 4 tabespoons to 4 L and boiled it on the stove like I saw them do in the Great British Bake Off Masterclass. I rolled the pretzels out on an unfloured surface and did not grease my baking sheet. I think they turned out well! I may try substituting margarine for the oil next time.

First time making pretzel and these were so yummy! I’m glad I read suggestions in the reviews to start with 3 cups of flour.  5 cups would’ve been too much IMO. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these twice in one week. The first time they came out great, the second time they were even better. I made a few little changes. First of all I reduced the sugar to 1/3 cup, as I don't particularly like breads to be sweet so I might cut back on the sugar even more. Secondly, I double proofed this time, and the dough was even  easier to work with. Lastly, I read a review which mentioned leaving the pretzels in the baking soda/hot water solution for ten minutes. I had just dipped them the first time and shoved them straight in the oven. This time, I left them in for several minutes and then left them for 5 to 10 minutes before putting them in the oven so the dough had time to rise and the result was 15 huge, fluffy pretzels. 

Edit: I chose both times to use the full amount of flour and just add 1/3 cup of water.

text:
This is a good solid recipe. I weighed all my ingredients as opposed to just cups and table spoons. I find weighing gives more consistency in baking. No need to flour the surface either. In fact I wouldn't suggest it. If your dough is smooth and right consistency it won't stick. A little more oil in recipe as suggested by other reviewer helps as well. If dough is to springy and wants to pull back when rolling out STOP rolling and allow dough to rest and relax for awhile

Display Name:
Geminicook
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I needed to make these for a potluck at work the next day. I was worried, because everyone says they are not good the next day. Well, mine turned out fantastic and fresh the next day! They were wonderful, the texture was perfect, and they tasted great! 

I had done some research to try and figure out how to make them still taste good and fresh the next day, and it worked! Here's what I did:  I made the dough 2 days before  (used less flour, about 4.5 cups), and froze the dough.  The next day I defrosted it in the 'fridge. That night, I rolled and shaped the pretzels, dipped them in the baking soda water, and baked them at 410 degrees for 6-8 minutes. They were just turning lightly golden. After they cooled, I put them on a cookie sheet lined with a kitchen towel, covered them with another towel, and then covered the cookie sheet, towels and all, with plastic wrap. 

At work the next day, I lightly misted the pretzels with a spray bottle of water to reinfuse some moisture.  I baked them in our little toaster oven at 410 degrees for 4 minutes. They were a perfect pretzel brown color! Slathered them in melted butter, added kosher salt to some, an "Everything" spice mix to others, and I had made some into nuggets that got coated with cinnamon sugar. I had several dipping sauces; pepper jack cheese sauce, cheddar cheese sauce, honey mustard, and a powdered sugar glaze for the cinnamon sugar nuggets. 

They were wonderful! They were as fresh as if I had made them all in one shot! M

userID:
2228868
Display Name:
Kristen Tyler Griffin
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/161589.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really good!  A few changes to adjust to my own personal tastes.  I like a chewy pretzel and used 3.5 cups of bread flour.  I mixed the dried ingredients and set them aside.  As soon as the yeast mixture was ready, I poured it into my KitchenAid mixer  bowl with the dough hook, added the oil , and 2 cups of the flour mix.  I turned on the mixer on low speed adding about 1/2 cup as soon as I could see the mix was combined, once all flour was added, about 2-3 minutes. Realizing it looked a bit dry, I added one additional tsp of oil.  It was the exactly what it needed.  I increased the speed to 3 for about 30 seconds and then on low (1) again until the dough ball had pulled away from the sides and was on the hook.  I pulled the dough off the hook.  Kneaded it about 1 minute more just until I saw the dough looked smooth and silky.  I placed it in an oiled bowl (or cooking spray). I let the dough proof for another hour and then portioned twelve pieces and shaped the dough.  Using a slated spatula, I dipped each pretzel in the hot water/soda  mixture, let it drip,  and sprinkled with some Kosher Salt.  Once in the oven, I baked them for about 6 minutes,  brushed on some melted butter, and then put back in for 3 more minutes.   

I then mixed up a quick little mustard dipping sauce (with a Tablespoon full of mayo,  1 1/2 tsps. of spicy brown mustard, 1 tsp of Dijon mustard, 1/2 tsp honey.)

Overall, a fairly easy recipe with delicious results.  Thank you!

This recipe is good. However, for all the people having trouble with a "bitter" taste, make sure you are NOT using aluminum pans to boil your pretzels! I'm very surprised it did not say this in the recipe. It causes a chemical reaction with the baking soda.

text:
Ok, now I don't write reviews ever.... but I made this recipe, and if it weren't for reading the comments before hand, I'm sure my pretzels would be a complete failure. First, I take off 1 star with this review for the fact that 450 F is WAY TOO HOT; you want to bake at 400 F otherwise you'll have burnt pretzels. Second, I take off another star because you shouldn't have to be going through comments to be able to successfully make what a recipe is for and 5 cups of flour is too much as well, you need 4 CUPS OF FLOUR. I'd take off more stars, because I've had better pretzels, but it's still a decent recipe that I didn't mind following. 3 Stars total. This recipe NEEDS to be modified, especially for the temperature.

***Also a little personal tip: Be sparingly with the kosher salt. You want to under-compromise, or you'll have pretzels that are too salty even to the slightest.

I am not a professional bread maker, but I  noticed the flour to water ratio is extremely imbalanced towards the flour. I made a batch using this recipe and instructions exactly giving the author the benefit of the doubt. Unfortunately my pretzels failed. Upon reading others reviews, most indicate they reduce the flour significantly. I feel that if one writes a recipe and gives detailed instructions, they should at least be accurate and not require modification. I would challenge the author to revise this recipe to one that is capable of being made.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4537571.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are very good, but I decided to give the recipe 4 stars because I wished it had more detail. I'm an experienced bread baker, but, since I've never made soft pretzels, I needed the kind of specifics that are in the Papa Dexler's Bavarian Pretzel recipe. There I learned that the bread ropes should be 15 inches long & the water for the baking soda mixture should be boiled, not just hot, like tap water. I think that difference probably affected the texture on the outside of the pretzel.  In spite of that, my family loved them, so I can say that this recipe is very forgiving. Based on another reviewer's suggestion, I used sea salt instead of kosher. I also sprinkled them with granulated garlic and Garlic Garlic by Pampered Chef, then brushed the pretzels with butter when they came out of the oven. That was delicious. The slight sweetness of the dough goes really well with that combination and I highly recommend it.

text:
I used this recipe for 2 reasons.

I followed the recipe by the book, and then split the amount into two separate bowls. One bowl I made Cinnamon and Sugar pretzels. The second were Pizza Pretzels. When i was mixing the dough by hand, i added the cinnamon to one bowl and the italian herb to the other. 

Rather than 12 pretzels, I had 9. 6 were the smaller cinnamon sugar ones, which are Scrumptious!! The other 3 were purposely larger so i could add my peppers, onion, cheese, spinach, and pepperoni on top. Those are in the over right now and look amazing!!

This was my first time ever making pretzels from scratch (2nd time total) and i will definitely use this recipe again!!

text:
I had my reservations about taking on a traditional ''trip to the mall highlight'' treat but this recipe looked relatively easy to follow. 

OH MY was it easy! 

The only change I made (and that was after reading the reviews) was decreasing the amount of flour to 4 cups (+/-). 

I kept mindful of the dough texture so as to have enough to make a manageably soft dough that held it's shape but wouldn't be tough.  

LOVED the baking soda trick! Other recipes DO NOT have that oh-so-important step! 

Definitely will be making more! The 1st batch is already gone! ;)

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/159305.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious and soft! I made this twice this week and the first time I only added enough flour for it to clean the bowl and the dough dissolved when I gave it it's baking soda bath. So I made them into sturdier rolls which were still delicious but not so soft pretzel-y. 

The second time I put in all 5 cups of flour, spooned and leveled and the dough was perfect and still soft after baking. 

The baking soda bath is important but it didn't give it enough of a chewy pretzel texture for me. I've seen recipes where you have simmering baking soda water and thought I will try that next time instead of just hot water. 

The dough and yummy and sweet and I had several people comment that they taste just like the mall pretzels. I've had them salted and with cinnamon sugar. I think I might cut out a little of the sugar next time for the salted ones.

None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Our family really likes this recipe! I make them regularly. My kids prefer them sprinkled with cinnamon and sugar and then baked and my husband and I prefer sea salt. And in case anyone was wondering, I do my dough in the bread machine (just don't include the 1 tsp of sugar) and put the liquid in first. It always comes out great and saves me the work. And the baking soda/water bath is necessary, though I think using 4 cups of water and 1/2 c. baking soda is a little much, especially since it's just for wetting the pretzels. Great recipe!!!

text:
These were divine! I've never made pretzels before and I generally find myself not fantastic at baking a darn thing but these turned out so perfect. Chunky, buttery, salty. My husband LOVES them. I read through a bunch of reviews before I dove in to baking and reduced the flour to 4 cups which was perfect. I added an extra teaspoon of oil also. Didn't need to flour any surfaces! The baking soda bath is an absolute must! And finally I slathered melted butter all over my pretzels when they were done. Way, way better than what you can find at the shops. Will be making these again and again, thank you so much!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe, though I replaced the oil with butter and used only 4 cups of flour instead of 5. I also didn't use as much hot water and baking soda (in the baking soda bath) because it's really a waste of ingredients if you use 1/2 a cup of baking soda just on this part. 3/8 a cup of baking soda paired with 3 cups of hot water creates the same effect, while saving your hard-earned ingredients. But overall, this recipe is really good if you just want something tasty and light to munch on.

text:
Yeast did NOT proof with that much water.  First batch was a scrap.  Second may not work right either.  The third batch I'm doing using manufacturer instructions for the yeast, and that one did proof okay.  Still waiting to see if the second and or third batches rise properly, and if so which.

*Edit.  After baking they did turn out alright.  They are a little dense, but I'm thinking that was due to my yeast problems. Still, not bad considering the yeast problems.  All in all, I will make them again, but I'll follow the manufacturer's yeast proofing instructions then add in the extra water when it comes time to mix with the flour.

I make these every year for our OktoberFest.  They take awhile, yeast breads always do, but they're quite simple to make.  I use my kitchen aid mixer dough attachment so no hand kneading required!  Add some beer cheese dip and you're set.  People request these now so I make them in batches and freeze ahead of time.  Thaw and warm, place in a napkin lined basket et voila!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677394.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are excellent. Made them for my daughter's class on her birthday as an alternative to the tired cupcakes. Her classmates loved them. I made the recipe dumping all the flour into a bowl and added the proofed yeast and water mixture into that. As others reviews noted, not all the flour would incorporate. Second time I made it, started with 3 cups flour, and added more to bowl as it mixed. Then, as I kneaded, I was able to get all except a half cup worked in. So, in total, I used 4 and a half cups. This is a fun recipe to do with kids. The kneading is hard unless you have a way to elevate a youngster so the work is below them. (I kneaded while my daughter threw more flour on the counter for me.) We made smaller pretzels so we could get 24 of them. They baked up to fit nicely on desert plates. I imagine full size would each likely fill a regular plate. Great recipe!

country:
None
text:
I've made these in the classic twist shape and in bite sized pieces, both ways they are phenomenal. I add my flour until the dough just wont absorb anymore. Its more intuitive than you'd expect . Definitely do the baking soda bath, but the water only has to be hot to dissolve the baking soda, you can dip your pretzels after the water has cooled. The only downside of this recipe is that they don't keep for very long, I highly recommend making them the day of. Even so, make a double batch - they go fast!

I did use some tips from others reviews; such as not as much flour, a bit more oil, not using flour on our rolling/shaping table, and lower oven temp, 400 degrees. The taste was great, we loved them!

text:
These were very good. Like Tiffany said, I used three cups of flour instead. Also, it may be helpful to note that I am not the sharpest tool in the shed; however, I forgot that baking soda reacts with water. I filled a bowl of water almost to the rim, and dumped the baking soda in all at once causing it to spill and foam all over my counter. You may want to add the soda a bit slower and use a bigger bowl for mixing it.

Display Name:
hlymbennett

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3088636.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
OH MY YUM! So, SO delicious!!! I was a little skeptical about this recipe at first, because whilst making the dough, it seemed like it took a lot of water (more than two addition tbsp, per the recipe) to get the dough to actually take form, and it honestly didn't seem to double in size, but rather just grew about 1/2, but I kept heart and am so glad I did! I'm generally used to making German pretzels, which are  different, especially when it comes to the crust. But, these were such a nice change and WILL be my go-to pretzel recipe from here on out. (I'm already clearing a spot in my permanent recipe book for them. :) ) I brushed them with softened butter fresh from the oven and as soon as I took a bite, I was SO overwhelmed by the soft texture, authentic taste, with just the perfect amount of crust. **I do recommend not overthinking when forming the strands that you'll kill the yeast and they won't re-take their form. As soon as you dip in the baking soda mixture, it automatically fluffs them up, so don't worry about making them too dense because that just isn't possible with this recipe! Do whatever you need to get your form right. They'll turn out just delightful! Will be making these again and again and again and again!

userID:
2107363
Display Name:
Carrie Rose
isPro:
False
followersCount:
6
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
171
favoritesCount:
226
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm giving this five stars because I really liked it and my family devoured them within about half an hour of taking them out of the oven!  But I want to experiment with the recipe to see if I can tweak it to make it better.  I used white whole wheat flour, and that worked very well (I imagine the pretzels would be even better with white flour, but this improved the nutritional profile).  I might also try reducing the sugar sometime to make these more nutritious, although the extra sweetness did taste good.  The dough was too dry to come together with the amount of flour called for, and I had to add water.  Next time I'll start with less flour and add more as necessary.  With the oven at 450, I was having trouble with the undersides of the pretzels getting browner than I liked.  This was alleviated somewhat by using a pizza stone, but next time I might try a lower oven temperature.  These tasted more bread-like than pretzel-like to me, and I wonder if dipping longer in the baking soda solution would help.  I just did a quick dip, but I saw another recipe that recommended a 45-second dip.  I also want to come up with some good sauces for these pretzels and experiment with coating them with cinnamon sugar or baking them with cheese.

My favorite recipe, can replace oil w/ butter to make it more buttery, but actually my favorite is substituting half of the oil with butter.

text:
Great!  A few tips: I suggest starting with only four cups of flour, kneading, then adding more as needed.  Secondly, I didn't need the whole four cups of hot water and baking soda.  Next time I will keep the ratio the same, but do less - 2 cups water and 1/4C baking soda.  Finally, next time I will bake longer at 350.  Mine came out doughy following the directions.

Display Name:
Ashlee Ann Steinberg

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1942607.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Like most people, I cut back the flour. 4 cups is plenty and I added a bit more while kneading. I followed another suggestion that recommended placing the pretzels on a paper towel right after the baking soda wash so the bottom isn't dripping with the wash. This helps the bottoms not burn while baking. 
I think a lot of people might miss the part in the very beginning, the quote, where it says to add butter on top of them right after they're out of the oven. I melted some butter and brushed it on, and it made them just prefect.
They're reminiscent of Auntie Anne's, with a yummy bread-like flavor. Over half of them were gone within 5 minutes.

userID:
4127857
Display Name:
ShellyCooks
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
25
favoritesCount:
141
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love making pretzels with the kids.  It's a great activity for days when we're stuck inside or we have guests.  I cut the dough into equal pieces and let the kids make their own shapes.  They each get a cutting board with a little flour to work on.  They have a ton of fun, the clean up is minimal, and it keeps us occupied for a good while.

I couldn't find my usual recipe so I followed this one b/c it has such a high score with over 1500 reviews.

I think these are a 3, my kids think they are a 5!
These are much sweeter than my usual recipe that calls for just a few tablespoons of sugar.  One of our guests who says she doesn't like pretzels loved how sweet they are and she probably ate half the plate!   

Usually I bring the water and baking soda to a boil and dunk them for 30-60 seconds.  They look lumpy and weird when they come out but they bake up beautifully.  I followed this recipe for the first batch to go in but they didn't get as nice of a crust as usual.  For the rest I dunked them in boiling water and then came out perfect.
Review:
Rating:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I changed the sugars to be 2/3 white sugar and 1/3 dry, powdered malt (not diastatic malt). Mixing the malt in with the flour, sugar and salt and there was no problem with it clumping up. 

I used my steaming convection oven for these and they came out huge.  I followed an earlier reviewer's advice and dropped the temperature to 415.  I might go even lower the next time around.

 The crowd raved over them.  I think this is a very forgiving recipe and look forward to making it again.I think there are 2 "twists" for the pretzel - the first is to twist the dough "rope" - that yields a very attractive finish to the product.  The second is the obvious loop / twist to put it into shape.

text:
It was an easy recipe to follow and the results are seriously fantastic!!! I only ended up needing 4 cups of flour and still had to add water. So I suggest only using a portion of what's called for and then adding more as needed. The 8 min cooking time is pretty exact too so don't walk away and forget them!

DO the last step with the baking soda and water!!! I only did it with my last pretzel. They all turned out delicious, but the one that was dipped in baking soda and water, browned nicer without drying out on top.

text:
Woke up this morning and decided to bake pretzels! Went on google, saw all the good reviews and helpful hits (thank you all for that; they were invaluable) and they were FANTASTIC!!! I would give the recipe a five if it weren't for the 4 cups of flower they recommend...Like everyone mentioned, 3 cups is perfect and I ended up add a few tsp of water. I put the oil in the bowl, as the recipe asks for and found it easy to roll out the dough. For those of you new to this kind of dough, it's a bit like rubber when you play with it.  Not that soft "bread dough" you might me used to. 
Now the trick is not to eat them all at once. Will be making them again soon.

text:
I tried this today. My son and I are gluten free. I used Bob's Red Mill all purpose baking flour and one teaspoon of xanthan gum. When we were ready. I did not put it in the water solution right away. I baked them on a silpat for about 5 mintues, then used a slotted spoon to dip and coat them in the hot water for a few seconds. After all the pretzels were dipped in the solution, I spread melted butter and salt on them and I baked for another five minutes. Perfect!

userID:
4841791
Display Name:
Rebecca Anderson
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
51
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3462516.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
YUM! Some notes: Kneading bread is often most successful done by hand, imo. You can feel when the dough is right.  Start with four cups of flour mix ingrediants in as directed. Just until it starts to form a ball and pulls away from the sides (think a messy knot not a smooth ball)Dump mixture onto a surface floured with a cup of flour sprad out knead mixture incorporating extra flour whenever it gets sticky for about 7-10minutes. Really get in there and grab and tear and push and fold. Depending on weather and altitude this may be enough. If the dough is not springy to touch and smooth  add a bit more up to the 6 cups in the recipe. (Bread dough isn't desgned as a specific measurement what works for one person will not always work every time you can't just treat it like a cake). After kneading let it rise as suggested.  One alternative to dipping pretzels is bathing them in the baking soda solution for 2 minutes (they get that really dark brown pretty color from this). Just let them soak and spoon the mixture up and over. When I picked them up I placed them in my hand with a paper towel on it to absorb some of the excess water (don't wrap it around just put the paper flat hold your hand flat put pretzel on flat hand for a second then move to baking sheet). I let them sit about 20 minutes then put in oven at 400 on middle and top racks for 5 minutes switched pans to the other rack baked 5 mins more. Moved to rack and spooned 3 tblspoons unsalted butter over all. To DIE FOR!!

text:
These are the best!  Way too much flour though.  Start with 4 c and add from there.  I also decided to make mini pretzel sticks.  They were about 1 1/2" around and 2-3" long. Making the sticks, I was able to make around 18 to 20 instead of the recommended 12.  The first time I made them I foolishly added all 5 cups of flour and there was so much I couldn't roll the dough out.  I almost threw the batch away but decided to make it, this is when I made the sticks, by squeezing the dough instead of rolling it; even with too much flour, they were still very good.  I have since figured out how the dough should feel.  I usually make 2 batches in a day (not a double batch, double batches often don't work and I don't want to waste all the ingredients).  My husband and kids are always begging me to make more and I am always willing to oblige!

Woke up this morning at 4:00 a.m. Checked out my daily e-mail from All Recipes and found this one. Since the hubby and I both LOVE pretzels and I had all the ingredients on hand I decided to give it a "twist & try"! I always read the reviews first and like others I cut down the flour to 4 cups but followed recipe exactly after that until coming to the baking soda solution. I just used 2 tsp. baking soda and 1 cup water (as suggested by another reviewer) and periodically warmed it up in the micro when it cooled down or between batches. Hubby loved them and he is EXTREMELY picky! I think we have a keeper except I really, really, really need practice at "twisting a pretzel". (as you can see by my photo)! Thanks!!!

text:
My five-year old son and I made these delicious, melt-in-your mouth, fluffy, soft pretzels today!  The recipe is very easy to follow and worked very well for a novice breadmaker, like me.  I followed many of the reviewers' suggestion to decrease the amount of flour, so I used 4 cups, but I still found the dough to be a bit dry.  To compensate, I had to add approximately 1 tablespoon of water, which made the dough pull together quite nicely.  Out of the oven, we brushed the tops with butter and sprinkled some with cinnamon sugar.  My husband declared that these pretzels are much better than the mall pretzels!

userID:
11156734
Display Name:
hollyclock
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yumyum! I love soft pretzels so I decided to give these a try.
I made a few small adjustments, and they turned out great!
1. I only used three cups of flour, but when I kneaded, I sprinkled a little more on every few minutes until the dough was no longer sticky.
2. I used mostly whole-wheat flour, which bumped up the overall healthiness and (I don't think) made them taste any worse.
3. I used 2 cups water and 1/4 Baking soda for the bath.
TIP: Use a thermometer to make sure your water for the yeast mixture is warm enough.
Boil the water lightly when making the baking soda mix, it will dissolve very easily.
After dipping them in the mix, let them drip for a second or two over the bowl before placing them on the pan, it will make cleaning easier. 
Melt butter and dip the pretzels in it for a tasty treat.
Put your oven at 325* instead, the bottoms will not be so brown.

text:
I really liked the flavor of these pretzels and they were pretty easy to make. I just wish that they were came out less puffy, if that makes sense because the traditional pretzels are thin and the coating on the outside is hard, while the inside is soft and chewy.  I did not get that from this recipe.  Maybe I did something wrong, but looking at all the pix submitted, I realize that their pretzels looked a lot like mine.  I was hoping for something different and I will continue to search for the best pretzel recipe out there.  Again, these taste good, but are not the consistency I am looking for.  These might need less yeast so that they are not as puffy and hold their safe better.

text:
Excellent recipe. Great flavor. I do recommend following advice of other people who have left a comment by reducing flour, substituting the oil with butter, and by rolling out dough thinner than what you would think. I had success with the dough the thickness of my smallest finger.                                      I also had great success in melting down 1/4 cup of butter, adding 1/4-1/2 tsp of garlic powder and basted the pretzels right out of the oven before I salted. Yum!

None
text:
My family and I didn't really care for these (we LOVE pretzelmaker).  I'm not sure if I did something wrong, as everything seemed to be going well, and I followed the recipe as stated except I used 4 cups of flour instead of five.  My dough was nice and pliable, and rose very well.  The pretzels were easy to roll out.  The problem was that the bottoms burned before they seemed cooked.  The pretzels ended up quite gooey in the middle, but burnt on the outside.  I tried lowering the oven temp to 400 and raising the rack, but it didn't help.  They still tasted okay once slathered in butter and salt, but I won't be making these again.

text:
This is an AWESOME recipe!  It is a bit tedious, but all steps are essential to get that perfect traditional pretzel taste.  I've made this recipe twice now, and the first time I didn't pull the dough enough and had trouble forming pretzels, but the second time it was perfect.  Soo good and received many compliments: "these are home made?!"

Another great alternative is to mix sugar, salt and brown sugar together and sprinkle that on top to make a 'sweet' version.

Thank you for the great recipe!

text:
We live in Germany and have come to love pretzels that are still made by boiling in lye solution instead of baking soda...but there is only so many you can eat.  These are so easy to make but I can't seem to make them fast enough, they disappear before i know it!  The recipe is very close to German pretzels and can be topped any way you like.  My daughter and wife prefer them brushed with melted butter then sprinkled with cinnamon and sugar while my son and I like them naked or with a touch of salt. We also have made sandwich rolls out of them, a nice change of pace over regular bread.

None
text:
I went to a football game with my family and bought something like this.  The pretzels that i bought were a little larger, but they tasted exactly the same!  They were amazing!  what I did to tweak the recipe a bit was, after the dough was made, cover it with plastic wrap and let it rise until it doubled its size.  Then, after you shape the pretzels, dip them in a baking soda mixture, then let it rise again for about an hour.  After you bake it, dip it in melted butter right away and viola!  Delicious pretzels!

OK, after all is  said and done, these were good.  I made the whole recipe exactly as is, no problems.  Dipped them in melted butter when they came out of the oven and sprinkled generously with cinnamon sugar.  Oh, the only change I made was 415 degrees for exactly 9 minutes on parchment paper, middle rack.  Perfect doneness, not too brown, a tiny bit chewy/doughy, soft and delicious!

text:
I am not a baker, but this recipe was easy to follow and the pretzels came out fantastic.  I tried them with cinnamon/sugar and they were a huge hit.  If you choose to add cinnamon/sugar to the tops of your pretzels, make sure to do it on a separate surface other than your baking sheet.   Otherwise it will get on your baking sheet (no matter how careful you are) and burn the bottoms of your pretzels.

None
text:
For Halloween Trick-or-treaters I decided to hand out pretzels along with candy and caramel apples, and this is the pretzel recipe I went to. They turned out excellent! Definitely one of my new favorite recipes. It's pretty simple and they tasted amazing. I ended up going with the full amount of flour listed in the recipe, just to make sure I made enough. The only changes I made were that I used butter instead of oil, and I cut the sugar down a little (1/4-1/3cup, I think). The dough ended up baking quite large even after rolling the strands of dough out very small, so if you're looking for small and neat pretzels, make sure you roll them very thin (Maybe pinky-finger size or smaller). They still tasted great, and I'm looking forward to making another batch soon!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading the user reviews and suggestions I made the following modifications. Changed the 5 cups of flour to 3 and 1/2 cups of flour. Changed the 1/2 cup of white sugar to 1/2 cup of brown sugar. Turned on the oven and then turned it off to get it slightly warm. Covered the bowl with a damp kitchen towel instead of the plastic wrap. Let sit in dark oven for 1.5 hours. Rolled the twists very long and thin. This allowed them to be airier. The rest of the recipe and directions I kept the same. I would possibly reduce the salt to 1 tsp for preference but its not necessary. For the ones we ate right away, I covered them in butter and dipped into a cinnamon and sugar mix. I also made a frosting drizzle using 1 cup of powdered sugar, 1 tsp of vanilla and 2-3tbs of half and half. These were amazing. Tasted just like any warm soft pretzel you would find in the mall. Keeping the modifications I would make these again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good recipe and tastes just like mall pretzels!  My fiance loved them!  However I did make adjustments according to some of the previous reviews:  kosher salt in the dough, decreased the flour (I used 4 cups and still had to add bit of extra water), covered the dough with a damp kitchen towel, lowered the temp to 400F, and brushed the pretzels with melted butter straight out of the oven.  I also used 1/3 cup sugar in the dough.  One important note--USE PARCHMENT PAPER.  I baked the first set of pretzels on a greased baking sheet and they completely stuck to the sheet!  So, I used lightly greased parchment paper for the second set and they came off just fine.  Also, I think the amount of the baking soda solution is wasteful--4 cups is excessive.  Next time I'll halve the solution--2 cups hot water with 1/4 cup of baking soda.  Thanks for the recipe!

While I wouldn't call these better than those from the mall, they are really good and a lot of fun to make. My husband and I took some time on this nice fall day to make them while enjoying one another's company. 

I replaced the vegetable oil with olive oil (since that's what I had on hand) and only used 4 cups of flour - even with four cups I found that I had to add a tablespoon of water. 

While the recipe ingredients do not call for butter, if you look to the right of the photo in the recipe, Christa mentions dipping them in butter (I brushed the tops of mine) to get the buttery flavor.

country:
None
text:
I made this in a bread machine, following reviews about using less (bread) flour and subbing margarine for oil. They look perfect,like many of the photos, but the texture inside is too soft for a pretzel- not chewy at all. Perhaps it was because they are not dipped in hot, simmering water for a minute first. Also, next time I will definitely cut back on the salt topping, since the coarse sea salt I used was a bit too crunchy and salty for my taste. I don't normally give a less-than-perfect rating for a recipe I didn't follow exactly, but if you're looking for a chewy soft pretzel, this probably isn't it- unless using the bread machine to make the dough and let it rise is the reason for the soft dough. Otherwise, they were tasty and will definitely not go to waste!

Have never made pretzels or bread before and these came out perfect for me!
Delicious with Cinnamon Sugar, but I like to stuff mine with Nutella and sprinkle with dessicated coconut after dipping in the baking soda solution, tastes like a yummy Bounty bar!
I do find that the next day, Cinnamon Sugar pretzels are a little soggy (due to brushing with butter?) - got around this by freezing after cooling and zapping in the microwave when needed.

Display Name:
jonathanham

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Short of cornbread and premade cookies/biscuits, I've never baked before. But after a late night craving for pretzels went unsatisfied, I decided to try making my own. 

I was worried about my first batch because the yeast I had was almost completely dead. When I proofed it, it barely foamed and the dough rose maybe a 1/4". I decided to push ahead because I had already mixed the flour, salt, and sugar. I didn't have any coarse kosher salt to give the pretzel that classic texture, but they surprisingly wound up tasting great. My roommate and I ate almost the whole dozen in a very short time.

I went to the store the next day and picked up some yeast and kosher salt and tried it again. This time the dough rose well, but unfortunately it was a bit too dry and I found it difficult to make the rope any thinner than about an inch. They still turned out really well and everybody loved them- they ware all gone by the next day! This has definitely turned me on to baking, I've already moved on to bread. Thank you for this delicious recipe!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Watching my youngest play, I realized my children have never had soft pretzels, so to allrecipes.com I went.  This in the only one I tried and yes, I did make a couple changes.  One, I used the dough cycle on my bread machine, the only change was cutting the flour to 4 cups and not needing the 1 tsp of sugar w/the yeast.  Two, I brushed w/butter after it was cooked and it made them definitely better.  The last 4 after brushing them, I sprinkled cin and sugar instead of salt.  Used table sea salt instead of kosher salt.  One of my sons fell off his chair when he started eating the cin and sugar one.  :-)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great!  A couple important things.  Use the top rack of your oven and try baking at about 400 instead of the recommended temp.  Also, when rolling out the strips -- try to make them as thin as possible.  You really can't get them too thin.  When I did my first batch they were thick enough that they almost tasted like a dinner roll rather than a pretzel -- but when I made them thinner -- well, they were FANTASTIC.  Also, try the Beer Cheese Pretzel and Dip (dip only, obviously) that is on this site as well.  They go great together.

text:
I'm not sure why this recipe is getting such great reviews, being that the water to flour ratio is incorrect. I added three cups of flour to the bowl with the dry ingredients and was expecting to add the other two cups after the wet ingredients were added, so I didn't make the dough too heavy right from the start. Turns out I never used the entire 2 cups I had put aside (except a tiny bit to flour my board while kneading). Without looking at other people reviews, I can see people having a very hard time with this dough.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE Auntie Anne's Pretzels and these come pretty close! I did make one change however. I used 4 cups of flour instead of 5. And was sure to do multiple coats of butter! One coat after baking for 3-4 minutes and the second coat after taking them out of the oven. PURE BUTTERY GOODNESS!! I made some jalapeno cheese variety as well! Which I think are best done in stick form. I first rolled the dough long, and cut into even sticks. Then I made small slits down the middle which I lined with some finely diced pickled jalapeno. Next, i covered them which shredded sharp cheddar cheese, no butter required! These were SOOOO DELICIOUS! and gone in seconds! I wish i had made more! But i will definitely be using this recipe again, however I will probably just make pretzel sticks--I personally think they are better portion sizing and they save time!

userID:
3943740
Display Name:
pickypickyeaters
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
9
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe. My family loves the mall pretzels and these are really close.     If you'd like a twist try turning these into hamburger buns.  After stretching/rolling them into ropes (slightly thicker than used for pretzels because you will need to slice it in two) loosely spiral them onto a baking sheet lined with parchment paper into the size buns needed. Cover with damp towel and place in warmed oven (appx. 170) which has been turned off and allow them to rise a 2nd time for 15-20 minutes.     Finish out with the same process and bake at about 400 for 9-10 minutes. Time can very depending on size of bun so you will need to watch them. Lightly brush with melted butter.    Let them cool then slice in two to create bun.     You will never want to use a regular bun again. A WONDERFUL, flavorful change to the ordinary hamburger. WE LOVE IT!    Note: I did follow the advise of cutting back on the flour by 1/2 C. and kneading them slightly longer. I also use melted salted butter instead of oil. Also, I cooked on higher rack to avoid the bottom from over cooking.    I yeild 4-5 regular 4" buns out of a batch.

Oh, man. While I was mixing the dough, I thought, "this dough is so tough." I did add three more tablespoons more and used a little less flour. I still  worried while I was shaping the pretzels that the finished product would be a flop; the dough really was tough. But! When it came out of the oven, all my fears were put to rest. AMAZING. I've made these a dozen times at least and they are always amazing. I use half whole wheat and half regular flour for a little more flavor.  My friends and I like to make pretzel bites instead of full sized ones because they're much easier to roll out and stick on a pan, you can eat so many of them, and they're more fun to dunk in frosting (milk, vanilla, and powdered sugar) after you cover them in butter and cinnamon sugar! Decadent dessert!

These pretzels were absolutely amazing! My friend and I made them and ate almost the whole batch. There was a bit too much flower in them, but I just added some milk until it came out to be a better texture. I'll DEFINITELY be making these again!

text:
so yummy!! It took about 2 hours for the first rise, then i formed the pretzels and let them rise for about 45mins,I used simmering baking soda/water instead of just hot, and i dipped each pretzels in it for 10 seconds. Then I brushed them with butter before baking (careful then brown really quickly in oven!)  After baking i brushed them with butter again and sprinkled sea salt on top. Ive always wanted to make homemade pretzels! will definately make again :)

yummmmmy... the pretzelmaker can keep their pretzel because I can now bake my own fresh pretzels right at home. thankx christa. this is an awesome recipe. I tried the "mall pretzels" from this site.... but the dough wasn't as I would have liked it to be... it didnt have that 1/2 cup of sugar or tbsp of oil so it made a dryer, tougher dough.  I personally don't like to judge a recipe before I try it.... so with that said, this recipe was excatly like as it states it is.. "soft buttery pretzel" chewy and sweet.  didnt change a thing... I did  dip it into the soda solution for at least 10 sec. or longer like one review suggested. and I also sprinkled some with cinnamon sugar for an even more sweeter touch.  thankx again christa. amazing. UPdate:09/29/11 ......made again... using my kitchenaid this time... definetly use it if u own one..and well i did use 5 cups of flour but did need to add a little more water....i made small pretzels for my little girls hands...they were soooo delicious like always.. thank again

text:
These were pretty good pretzles. I used about 4 cups of flour to begin with and added little by little more to the consistency of my liking. I baked for less than the 8 min otherwise they would have gotten burnt. I coated some with kosker salt, some cinnamon and sugar, but the best were the ones I put jalapenos and jack cheese on. The cheese didn't burn and they were this perfect chewy softness. Only con about these was that bottoms stuck to pan a wee bit, but not burnt... just really browned due to the baking soda and hot water solution.

text:
These were good but not quite as great as I expected with all the great reviews stating they tasted better than the mall pretzels. The mall's is far better!! But if your in the mood for some quick pretzels without going out these wern't half bad. I made them exactly as the recipe stated with a few exceptions based on other reviewers. I used 4 cups of flour & cut the baking soda in half. I also baked at 415 rather than 450 & that was more than enough....450 would have burnt them! Once they were baked I brushed with melted butter & sprinkled cinnamin & sugar over them. They were nice & chewy! A nice treat for my hubby & I but no where near mall quality! I would still make them again though.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this nearly as-is and they were absolutely amazing. I had never even thought of making home made pretzels until I saw this recipe featured. I used half AP flour and half 100% whole wheat flour. I also substituted the sugar with turbinado cane sugar, which is tastier and more healthy. Other than that, I followed this recipe to the letter and it blew me away. A couple of tips: DON'T change the baking temp, and bake for 8 minutes - no more, no less. Also, I did end up brushing them with melted butter, right out of the oven. They are so shiny, beautiful, and tasty. Oh and give your baking sheet a liberal greasing. Otherwise you'll be bagging chunks of pretzel :-)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I can't give it 5 (though I want to!) because I changed it a little.  OMG These are SO good!  They were gone in less than 5 minutes, the kids and adults all loved them.  I used 1 1/2 packets of yeast, 1 1/2 c water, a bit less than 1/2 c sugar, and 2 TBS melted butter in place of the veg oil... Oh and 4 1/2 c flour.  They were incredible!  I left some plain and the others I sprinkled with a mixture of parmesan cheese, garlic powder, and a tiny bit of black pepper (after brushing on melted butter when they came out of the baking soda bath).  If you're thinking about it, YES TRY IT!  I had no problems handling the dough and am not sure why others did.  I followed another's advice and mixed the sugar, yeast, salt, and water at first.  I added the melted butter, stirred, then added the flour.

These were AMAZING!I made them exactly as is and they were divine, my entire house smelled like Auntie Anne's Pretzel shop. The only change I made that I think is completely necessary is to melt a stick of unsalted butter. When you pull them out of the oven, drizzle the butter over them.    Remember these will puff up a bit when you bake them. Also, these are BEST straight out of the oven. I made these on a Saturday for work on Monday and they weren't quite as good.

text:
Seriously amazing pretzels... soft & chewy on the inside with a browned crust on the outside that softens slightly with the butter.    Changes I made:  only used 4 cups flour (half unbleached white, half wheat), used brown sugar instead of white, and made this in the bread machine on dough cycle.  Absolute best topping HANDS DOWN was parmesan-garlic that I made by whizzing some fresh parmesan and garlic powder (the kind with parsley & herbs in) in a mini-food processor.  Sprinkle over the pretzels after you butter the tops.  The only change I would make is to reduce the sugar to 1/3 cup.  They were just a bit too sweet (even with sweet toppings on, the sweetness was too much and tasted like sweet bread instead of a pretzel).  And I am a HUGE sweet lover!  Husband and party-goers were hovering near the stove to claim pretzels as they were coming out of the oven and gobbled them up as fast as I could get them made.  MAKE A DOUBLE BATCH...!!

Bread Machine Bakers:  It can be done! userID:

Display Name:
Freedom Amber Kenney
isPro:

3
favoritesCount:
82
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4046555.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
YUUUUUMMMMMMMMMMMYYYYYY! These pretzels are fantastic. I AM NOT a baker, but these turned out excellent. I listened to other reviewers and only used 4 cups of flour. I also used quick rise yeast and let it sit for about 45 minutes. I found that if you want a more bready (Auntie Anne's) pretzel then you want to just dip the pretzels in the baking soda mix for about 5-10 seconds. If you want a more chewy (Pretzel Time) pretzel then you want to soak for 30 seconds to 1 minute. I put the salt on directly after the baking soda bath and it was fine. Only put salt on the ones you plan to eat that same day as they seem to soak in by the next day. You can freeze them, dip them in water and then sprinkle salt, this is what we did at the theme park, butter is not needed and water makes the salt stick better. This do taste buttery although there is no butter. FYI- Jalapeno Cheddar dip( .85) from Little Ceasars goes AMAZINGLY with this.

Ok, so these were good, but I have two complaints.  One, why are they called buttery where there is no butter in the entire recipe?  I brushed it on after baking.  Two, the soda bath got all puddled under the pretzels and they were black underneath.  Ugh.  I read some review of another pretzel that said to toss the pretzel on a paper towel before putting on the baking sheet.  Just toss it on, on one side, for like 1 second.  Then that part is the bottom (the part that touched the towel).  Otherwise, these were pretty good. And really easy to make.  Like other reviewers said though--too much flour!  Altogether yummy tho!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Mmmm, soooo good! I mixed up the sugar, water, and yeast in a small bowl, and let it sit while I placed the dry ingredients in my bread machine. (I started with 4 cups of flour.) When the yeast mixture was ready, I added it to the bread machine and let it do it's thing for 4-5 minutes. I didn't need to add any more flour! They turned out so yummy, much better than the recipe I used to use!

Amazing!  My husband has NEVER liked soft pretzels and he ate two right out of the oven.  I brushed them with butter while hot and sprinkled half with cinnamon/sugar and the other half with a little more salt. I used high gluten flour, it should be noted that my dough did not rise quickly and never did double but was soft and easy to work with after an hour or so.  I will never pay for mall pretzels again!

country:
None
text:
These were delicious... the second time around! I didn't proof the yeast first time and think that batch must have been a dud. The second (good) batch I doubled the yeast and sugar while it proofed let a second rise after rolling out the dough and forming the pretzels. I boiled the pretzles for about a minute in the soda solution and used paper towels to get some of the water off before putting them on the baking tray. They came out golden and chewy inside, just the way we like them, and I brushed them with a little garlic powder mixed in with salted butter. Labour intensive, but delicious. I live in Egypt and can't get the "mall" pretzels here, so this was a nice treat to bring home a little closer, thanks for posting!

text:
I had my doubts because I am such an Auntie Ann Pretzel lover, but these are every bit as good. I added melted butter to them right when they came out of the oven and they taste wonderful.  The thinner you roll them the better they'll turn out, if you don't roll them thin you run the risk of them being a bit doughy in places.  Also, I used five cups of flour but had to add way more water, I think you can get away with four cups.  These mess up the kitchen a bit, but are worth the clean up time.

Oh my gosh, these were so much fun to make and really good!  My 11yr old and I had a blast. Rolling the dough out to make the pretzel shape was a little hard for us but it had my daughter and me cracking up at the shapes we created.  Just the memories alone were great!  I used the parchment paper as instructed but, I wont next time b/c it didn't just peel off.  I've never seen parchment paper cook on like that before and we use it w/almost all of our baking.  Next time we will spray a baking sheet with Pam.  Aside from that, these were great and we will make them again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I substituted the oil for butter and instead of the plain old cinnamon sugar or salt, I made an almond topping. All you need is to grind the almonds into the size of your liking (I used a food processor), add sugar to taste, and I added a bit of tiny butter pieces into there though I don't know if that had any effect on the outcome. Maybe because I'm impatient when kneading the dough to combine the ingredients that I found adding the extra 2 tablespoon of water necessary. And just to make my pretzels taste all good (but fattening), I brushed them with clarified butter right after taking them out of the oven. Just know that 8 minutes is all you need to bake these beauties.(I made two pretzels with a 3-serving size recipe and they came out done and gold). Thanks, Christa!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/106812.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made these and they did turn out quite well. The oven temp at 450 was too high, I turned down to 400 and baked for about 5-6 mintues to get a nice golden brown color. I thought maybe I wrote the recipe down wrong, as it called for 1/2 cup baking soda, but I checked and that was the recipe. Mine tasted like it was coated in baking soda, but other than that they were good. Next time I will use less baking soda in the water for dipping before baking. Maybe less sugar, as I want mine more savory instead of sweet. I used a dipping sauce of hot mustard (found on this website), but it did NOT work very well. When the vinegar in the mustard mixed with the soda solution on the pretzel it fizzed,and it fizzed in my mouth while chewing and down to my stomach....so I suggest buying the hot mustard from the store...which I will do asap!

text:
These were wonderful. I made a double batch and worked them into little twists for my daughter to bring in for her class snack. The only changes we made were adding the butter that I used to grease my hands during the kneading process. (It was a touch dry, so I adjusted) Also, we boiled our baking soda mix, and let the pretzels boil until they floated (10 seconds) and then baked them for 6-7 minutes @450. We did a butter dip and then coated with cinnamon sugar. Spectacular!

I actually added a third more to the recipe as I accidentally put in 2 more tsps. of yeast. So I added more water and flour. Dough came out a little hard and I was worried about it. Surprisingly, after baking, the pretzels came out really soft. Following some of the reviewers' tip, I drizzled melted butter as soon as they popped out of the oven. The taste is heavenly!! They really taste so much like the ones at the Pretzelmaker. With this recipe, I don't need to go to Yorkdale Mall here in Toronto, just to get that treat. My kids readily devoured them even though they're still hot! Thanks! This recipe is definitely a keeper.

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:

userID:
1929975
Display Name:
Katie
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These pretzels are so good!  I use my mixer with the dough hook to make the dough the night before I want to make the pretzels.  Then I let the dough sit in the fridge overnight, and then take it out and let it rise on the counter for a few hours until it is doubled.  Rolling out the pretzels is the hardest part, it takes a while to get them really thin!  They get pretty fat when you cook them.  Also, I only cook them for about 6 and a half minutes or they start to get really dark, but I think my oven is off temp.  They are best to eat on the day they are made, but if you have some left over the next day you can stick them in the microwave to soften back up!
Review:

5

64
favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3101450.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These turned out GREAT!!! I followed other reviewers advice and decreased flour to 4 cups. Threw everything (I also added about 2 tbsp of honey) into the kitchen-aid w/ the dough hook for 7 minutes. Once it had doubled, I didn't even bother taking it out of the bowl and flouring it. I simply grabbed chunks out of the bowl and rolled them in my hand "snake" style. Dipped in the baking soda/water mix and threw them on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. I didn't have the patience to shape these, so they turned out to be pretzel nuggets/sticks. Once they were baked, I brushed both top and bottom with melted butter. These are to die for!!

text:
WOW WOW WOW!! IF YOU MAKE THE ROPE EXTRA LONG ABOUT THE SIZE OF A PENCIL (ABOUT 3 FEET0. YOU WILL NEVER NEVER NEVER HAVE TO GO TO THE MALL FOR THESE. I GLAZED A FEW OF THEM WITH HONEY BEFORE AND AFTER THEY CAME OUT OF THE OVEN AND I SALTED A FEW. MAKE SURE YOU BUTTER THEM BEFORE THEY ACTUALLY GO IN THE OVEN, THEY WILL HAVE A NICE EXTRA BUTTERY YUMMMMMMY TASTE TO THEM. THANKS FOR SHARING THIS RECIPE. ITS IS SO MUCH BETTER AND EASIER THAN THE OTHER SOFT PRETZEL RECIPE.

This is the first recipe I have ever made that used yeast.  I was kind of scared, but it turned out fabulous.  For ease I often just roll them straight and cut them into bite size pieces after baking.  These are best fresh.  I made some to take a day later and they were not very good.  I have played around with the flour, and find it is best to use slightly less than the recipe calls for and adding as needed. Enjoy!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/388708.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great! I used a little more than 4 cups flour, 3 bread flour and 1+ AP, a heaping 1/4 cup sugar. Used Kitchen Aid for mixing. Got too much flour on my counter making it difficult to roll, so had to get my hands wet. Got the hang of shaping by the last few. I cut 16 pieces, using a couple to roll cheese and/or ham in. Really good. The pieces were plenty big for the regular pretzels. I don't think you need the half cup of soda and 4 cups hot water, not all the soda dissolved and one cup of water in a shallow bowl with a couple Tbs water probably would have done it - hold the pretzel upside down holding the ends that meet the bottom so the pretzel stays together. I held it up for a few seconds to stretch it out a bit. My first few were a bit fat, but the last ones looked perfect. Will definitely make these again!

text:
Yum, yum, yum!  This is a great recipe.  Keep in mind you are making a type of bread.  You do not need to use all of the flour.  I only use about 3 cups each time. Dip in soda mixture, sprinkle with salt, bake at 400 for 8-10 minutes then brush with butter.  If you would like a cinnamon sugar pretzel - do not sprinkle with salt - Bake, brush with butter and sprinkle with a cinnamon sugar mixture.  AMAZING!! Thanks for the awesome recipe!

I'm definitely what you would call a "novice" when it comes to cooking and baking. My mom and I LOVE soft pretzels, and our favorite mall pretzel shop closed, plus five dollars per pretzel is a bit much! 
I tried this recipe for my first time tonight and it was AWESOME! They tasted just like Auntie Anne's. Granted, my form wasn't the greatest, but I took advice from other reviewers by raising the oven rack, and using parchment paper on my pan. I also lowered the oven temp to 400 degrees, but I think it was a bit too low for the 8 minutes bake time. A few tweakings and it will be perfect! Thanks!

Great recipe!

text:
Oh my goodness. These are amazing! I whipped up a batch and I'm having a hard time keeping out of them! I used 3 cookie sheets, 1 with butter on the pretzels, and 2 with the soda wash. The ones with the soda wash browned really well with that slight crisp outside. Definately use the soda wash. The buttered ones are cooked through, but are white. Used melted butter instead of the oil, and 4 cups of flour, which still was a bit much, but got it to work. I put garlic powder and parmesean cheese on mine after they were cooked. Before I made these I was trying to figure out what to dip them in, but they don't need it. Making again and again. Yum!

text:
I've never worked with such a tough dough before!! Will defenitely use 4 cups of flour as opposed to 5. With the 5 cups of flour, I was adding a ridiculous amount of extra water, just to be able to work the dough. The flavor was good, although my husband found them a bit too sweet. Also, I accidentally added the cinnamon-sugar to the pretzels before baking and this is a huge no-no!! It caused some sort of chemical reaction that I wasn't aware of and they turned black on the outside!!! LOL! However, My stepson loved them and he is a pretzel lover (not the cinn-sugar ones of course!!) I would recommend dipping them into melted butter after they come out of the oven, wonderful!!

text:
Wow! After watching tv and seeing someone buy a pretzel from a street cart, I knew I needed to make some! These turned out perfect! My rolls didn't get as thin as I read in the reviews, so I thought I'd have to cook them longer. Nope, 8 minutes was perfect for my awfully shaped pretzels (they looked more like lumps than anything).

My only change was that I used brown sugar instead of white. Also, in the beginning, I only mixed in 4 cups of flour. My dough didn't get near wet enough! I added another 1/4c of warm water and probably kneaded in the last 3/4 - 1 cup flour that I didn't add in the beginning. Perfect perfect perfect! Going to eat some more!

These pretzels were delicious, I followed the recipe exactly but probably used only 3 and 3/4 cups of flour.  They do taste similar to mall pretzels, but I will try and make them skinnier next time.  They were very thick.  It may require baking 2 seperate pans in order to have enough room on the pan to stretch them out.  All in all, these were very good.  I sprinkled some with parmesan, some with cinnamon and sugar and some with kosher salt.

I took notes on some of the reviews and used 31/2C flour (reserving 1/2C for kneading), 1/4C sugar, let rest after dipping in baking soda solution, egg wash before cooking and butter after.  (I did 6 cinn/sugar & 6 salt)  They came out of the oven 10 min ago and I tried them, they were very tasty, but not chewy like a pretzel should be.  Would make a great bread or breadstick recipe!

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/20653.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed another reviewer's advice and allowed these to rest a few minutes prior to baking, and then brushed with egg wash before popping in the oven.  After baking for the allocated 8 minutes, I brushed them with melted Cinnamon/Sugar Country Crock and then sprinkled with Domino Cinnamon/Sugar mix.  
I followed the recipe exactly, and these came out fine.  The dough was easy to work with, and I had no trouble at all in rolling out ropes approx. 3 feet long.  Once baked, they puff up quite a bit and look very appealing.  The taste is somewhat bland, but it's not because your flour might be stale, I think the recipe needs more salt.  Other than that, I would make these again. They were very easy and fun to make.
Thank you!
